105.01  DESIGNATION OF WARD BOUNDARIES.
   The City is hereby subdivided into four wards which are equal in number to
the members of Council who are to be elected by wards. The boundaries of the
wards, which are determined to be as nearly equal in population as is
practical, are defined in this chapter.
(Ord. 5351. Passed 12-17-91.)
105.02 FIRST WARD.
   The First Ward shall be that area in the corporation encompassed by the
following boundaries: Beginning at the point of intersection of the centerlines
of Dotterer and South Clinton Streets; thence southwesterly on and along the
centerline of South Clinton Street to the point of intersection with the
centerline of Emblanche Street; thence westerly on and along the centerline of
Emblanche Street to a point on the easterly line of Miami and Erie Canal;
thence southwesterly along the east line of the Miami and Erie Canal to the
southerly corporation limit; thence in various directions following the
corporation line, generally in an easterly direction, to its point of
intersection with the Defiance and Richland Township line; thence northerly on
and along the said township line to the centerline of Cleveland Avenue; thence
westerly along the centerline of Cleveland Avenue to the southerly side of the
Auglaize River; thence westerly on and along the southerly side of the Auglaize
River to a point; said point being the point of intersection with a line
extending the centerline of Dottier Street southeasterly; thence northwesterly
and along the extended centerline and centerline of Dotterer Street to the
point of beginning.
(Ord. 7285. Passed 6-28-11.)
105.03  SECOND WARD.
   The boundaries of the Second Ward are as follows: All that area within the
corporation between the Maumee and Auglaize Rivers, except the area previously
described as being in the First Ward.
(Ord. 5351. Passed 12-17-91.)
105.04 THIRD WARD.
   The boundaries of the Third Ward are as follows: All that area within the
corporation lying north of the Maumee River.
(Ord. 5351. Passed 12-17-91.)
 
105.05 FOURTH WARD.
   The boundaries of the Fourth Ward are as follows: All that area within the
corporation lying south and east of the confluence of the Auglaize River and
the Maumee River, except the area previously described as being in the First
Ward.
(Ord. 5351. Passed 12-17-91.)

107.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, "maintains," "personal information" and "system"
shall have the same meanings as provided in Ohio R.C. 1347.01.
(Ord. 3624. Passed 3-7-78.)
107.02 PROMULGATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE RULES; PURPOSES.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to promulgate administrative rules as are
deemed necessary to accomplish the following purposes:
(a)    To authorize any function of the City that is necessary and relevant to
the government of the City and which is not otherwise required or authorized by
State or Federal statutes, by ordinances, resolutions or codes of the City or
by other administrative rules adopted by officers or bodies of the City;
(b)    To authorize the use of various forms, documents and records that are
necessary and relevant to the functions and government of the City;
(c)    To collect, maintain and use personal information that is necessary and
relevant to the functions and government of the City, in such records systems
as may be necessary and convenient to the governing of the City; to require
that persons provide personal information and other information to the City;
and to eliminate personal information from such systems when it is no longer
necessary and relevant to the functions and government of the City;
(d)    To determine the methods by which employees, officers and other
representatives of the City shall inform persons asked to supply personal
information for a records system and whether or not they are legally required
to do so or if they may refuse to supply the information:
(e)   To ensure that personal information is maintained in records systems with
such accuracy, relevance, timeliness and completeness as are necessary to
ensure fairness in determinations made with respect to subject persons on the
basis of the information;
(f)    To establish reasonable means to protect and safeguard personal
information in records systems from anticipated threats or hazards to the
security of the systems;
(g)    To provide for methods of informing and training employees and officers
of the City who are responsible for the operation or maintenance of personal
information systems or for the use of personal information;
(h)    To designate one individual who is directly responsible for each
personal information system;
(i)    To provide disciplinary measures, that are consistent with civil service
regulations, to be applied to employees of the City who initiate or otherwise
contribute to any disciplinary or other punitive action against any individual
who brings to the attention of appropriate authorities, the press or any member
of the public evidence of unauthorized use of information contained in the
system, as required by Ohio R.C. 1347.05(D);
(j)    To designate officers or employees of the City as records coordinators
and records officers and to specify the powers, duties and functions of such
records coordinators and records officers;
(k)    To establish a procedure to be followed by all departments, divisions,
boards, commissions and units of the City in preparing and filing notices
pertaining to personal information systems that are required by Ohio R. C.
1347.03;
(l)    To establish procedures, consistent with Ohio R.C. 1347.08, to be
followed by officers and employees of the City in providing access to personal
information in any records system upon the request of persons who are the
subject of the personal information, including the establishment of reasonable
fees to be charged to persons who request copies of personal information;
(m)    To establish procedures, consistent with Ohio R.C. 1347.09, to be
followed in receiving, processing and resolving disputes concerning personal
information, which disputes are raised by persons who are the subject of the
information; and
(n)    Such other purposes as may be necessary to comply with Ohio R.C. 1347.05
(B) and other applicable State or Federal statutes pertaining to privacy.
      (Ord. 3624. Passed 3-7-78.)
107.03  INTERPRETATION OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter and the administrative rules adopted under the authority of
this chapter shall not be construed to prohibit the release of public records
or the disclosure of personal information or other information in public
records that is required to be kept open for inspection by Ohio R.C. 149.43, or
to authorize a public body to hold an executive session for the discussion of
personal information or other information if the executive session is not
authorized under Ohio R.C. 121.22(G).
(Ord. 3624. Passed 3-7-78.)
CHAPTER 109
Democracy Day
109.01   Established; public hearings.
109.02   Letter to congress.
109.03   End of hearings.
 
109.01  ESTABLISHED; PUBLIC HEARINGS.
   Beginning the year 2015, the Mayor and City Council shall designate one day
in the month of February following the November federal elections, “Democracy
Day.” On this day, the Mayor and City Council shall sponsor a Public Hearing in
a public space within the City. The City shall publicize the Public Hearing on
its website and through area media at least one (1) month in advance of the
Hearing. The Public Hearing will examine the impact of political contributions
of corporations, unions, PACS and Super-PACS on the City. The Mayor and at
least one (1) City Councilperson shall submit testimony at the public hearing.
In addition, all citizens of Defiance will be permitted to submit oral
testimony for a period of at least five (5) minutes per citizen.
(Ord. 7598. Passed 3-11-14.)
109.02  LETTER TO CONGRESS.
   Within one (1) week following the Public Hearing, the Mayor shall send a
letter to leaders of the Ohio House and Senate, and Defiance’s U.S.
congressional representative, and both Ohio U.S. Senators stating that the
citizens of Defiance in November 2013 voted in support of a Citizens’
initiative calling for a constitutional amendment declaring:
   (a)   Only human beings, not corporations, are legal persons with
constitutional rights.
   (b)   Money is not equivalent to speech, and therefore regulating political
contributions and spending is not equivalent to limiting political speech.
      (Ord. 7598. Passed 3-11-14.)
109.03 END OF HEARINGS.
   The bi-annual Public Hearing will cease if and when a constitutional
amendment reflecting the principles set forth in Section
109.02 is ratified by 3/4 of State legislatures.
(Ord. 7598. Passed 3-11-14.)

121.01 MEETINGS.
   In addition to regular meetings of Council, special meetings of Council may
be called as provided in the City Charter, provided that notice to the news
media, as to the time, place and purpose of the meeting, is given, as provided
by law. If the Council President or any Council member has more than four
unexcused absences from any regular, study or special meeting during any
calendar year, there shall be deducted from his or her annual salary forty
dollars ($40.00) for each unexcused absence over four. (Ord. 7836. Passed 8-9-
16.)
121.02 POWERS; AUTHORITY RE CONTRACTS.
   The powers of Council shall be legislative only. Council shall perform no
administrative duties and shall neither appoint nor confirm any officer or
employee in the City Government, except those of its own body, unless otherwise
provided by the City Charter. All contracts requiring the authority of Council
for their execution shall be entered into and conducted into performance by the
board or officers having charge of the matters to which they relate. After
authority to make the contracts has been given and the necessary appropriation
made, Council shall take no further action.
121.03 ATTENDANCE OF DEPARTMENT AND DIVISION HEADS AND MAYOR AT MEETINGS.
   The department heads shall attend the meetings of Council when specifically
requested by Council, through the Mayor, or solely by the Mayor, to do so and
shall answer questions relative to the affairs of the City under their
respective management and control. Division heads may be requested to attend
through their various department heads and if the department head requests
their attendance, they shall comply. The Mayor’s attendance shall be governed
by Section
3.06(1) of the City Charter.
121.04  INSURANCE BENEFITS OF COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   (a)   Members of Council electing to enroll in the Buckeye Ohio Risk
Management Association-City of Defiance Health and Dental Care Plan or in any
other program pursuant to which the Municipality provides accident, accidental
death, accidental dismemberment, dental, health, health maintenance,
hospitalization, life, prescription drug, surgical, vision care, wellness or
similar insurance coverage for the benefit of municipal employees and/or
officials shall pay one hundred percent (100%) of the premiums assessed by the
underwriter for the coverage extended to the member of Council and his or her
insured dependents.
   (b)   Subsection (a) hereof does not apply to costs now or hereafter
assessed pursuant to statute for benefits provided members of Council pursuant
to the general laws of Ohio including, without limitation, laws pertaining to
Workers’ Compensation and public employees’ retirement.
(Ord. 6768. Passed 2-6-07.)
121.05 RULES OF CONDUCT AND PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The “Rules of Conduct and Procedure, Defiance City Council” as
amended, revised, rearranged, renumbered, consolidated and filed with the
Clerk, are adopted.
   (b)   Nothing in this section, nor in any amendment of or revision to the
Rules of Conduct and Procedure adopted by this section, shall invalidate any
prior act of Council nor limit the enforcement or alter the meaning of any
ordinance or resolution heretofore enacted or adopted.
(Ord. 7693. Passed 2-3-15.)

129.01 EMERGENCY POWERS.
   (a)    Whenever the Mayor determines that an emergency exists as a result of
any natural disaster or man-made calamity, or that there is a clear and present
danger that riot, insurrection, mob action or other civil disturbance may cause
injury or damage to persons or property, the Mayor shall proclaim, in writing,
the existence of the emergency and the time of its inception and shall issue a
proclamation through the news media and by other means that he or she deems
advisable, with a copy (or notification) to the President of Council.
   (b)    When the Mayor determines that an emergency exists, the Mayor shall
have the power to impose, by proclamation, any or all of the following
regulations necessary to restore the peace and order of the City:
      (1)    Prohibit or limit the number of persons who may gather or
congregate on the public highways or public sidewalks, or in any outdoor place,
theater, restaurant, place of public assembly or commercial establishment to
which the public has access;
      (2)    Restrict or prohibit movement within, above or beneath the area
which, in his or her judgment, is imperiled by the public danger or emergency;
      (3)    Establish a curfew during any hours of the day or night as he or
she deems advisable and prohibit persons from being out of doors during the
curfew;
      (4)    Prohibit or restrict the retail sale, distribution or giving away
of gasoline or other flammable or combustible products in any container other
than the gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
      (5)    Order the closing of gasoline stations and other establishments
engaged in the retail sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of
flammable or combustible products;
      (6)    Prohibit or restrict the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving
away of firearms or ammunition of any character;
      (7)    Order the closing of any establishment or portion thereof engaged
in the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms or ammunition;
      (8)    Prohibit or restrict the carrying or possession on the public
streets or sidewalks, or in any public park or other public place, of a weapon
or any object intended to be used as a weapon, including, but not limited to,
firearms, bows and arrows, air rifles, sling shots, knives, razors, broken
bottles, fire bombs, missiles of any kind, clubs, blackjacks, chains or similar
items;
      (9)    Prohibit or restrict the retail sale, distribution, dispensing or
giving away of acids, caustics, chemicals or other substances capable of being
used singly or in combination to cause injury or damage to persons or property;
      (10)    Call upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and
organizations within or without the Municipality to assist in preserving and
keeping the peace within the Municipality; and/or
      (11)    Prohibit the sale of beer, wine or intoxicating liquor.
   (c)    Any emergency proclaimed in accordance with this section shall
terminate seventy-two hours after the issuance thereof, or upon the issuance of
a proclamation determining that an emergency no longer exists, whichever occurs
first. However, the emergency may be extended for additional periods of time as
determined necessary by the Mayor.
129.02 REPORTS TO COUNCIL.
   The Mayor shall communicate to Council from time to time, but no less
frequently than annually, a statement of the finances of the City and other
relevant information as to the general condition of the affairs of the
Municipality as he or she deems proper or as may be required by Council.
129.03 TRAVEL ALLOWANCE; CITY CAR.
   The Mayor shall receive an automobile travel allowance or a City car, at the
discretion of Council. (Ord. 5188. Passed 7-24-90.)
129.04  ADMINISTRATIVE SECRETARY.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to hire an Administrative Secretary to aid
him or her in the execution of his or her duties.

131.01  JOB DESCRIPTION.
   The job description for the City Administrator is as follows:
(a)    Job Responsibilities. The City Administrator shall be under the
administrative direction of the Mayor. He or she shall plan and manage City
governmental operations and perform other related duties as required.
(b)    Qualifications. The City Administrator shall have any combination of
training and work experience which indicates possession of the skills,
knowledge and abilities listed below. An example of an acceptable qualification
for this position is a B.S. Degree in Public Administration or Business
Administration and five years experience as an administrative level supervisor
in city government (or equivalent), of which at least two years must be in a
supervisory capacity.
(c)    Illustrative Duties. The City Administrator shall:
(1)    Manage and direct the daily operations of the safety and service
functions of City government; maintain communication with departmental
supervisory personnel to ensure that departments are functioning in compliance
with City policy and procedure; provide direction to supervisors concerning the
establishment and obtainment of short range and long range departmental
objectives; and coordinate City departments toward common goals;
(2)    Develop policies and procedures relative to City governmental operations
and inform departmental supervisors, through verbal or written communication,
of policy or procedural changes relative to their department operation;
(3)    Meet and confer with employee organizations; analyze requests, discuss
requests with affected City personnel; and prepare responses to organizations;
(4)    Review departmental budgets developed by supervisory personnel; comply
with budget requests; and submit the same to the financial manager with
recommendations for approval;
(5)    Oversee expenditures of moneys to ensure adherence to approved
departmental budgets;
(6)    Conduct regular meetings with supervisory personnel on an individual or
group basis;
(7)    Attend Council meetings to express special concerns, to provide
information and to recommend measures for adoption; prepare reports on work
progress, etc., for review by Council; and prepare all work-study agendas;
(8)    Serve as an official City representative in public meetings; and
(9)    Represent the City in dealings with the news media on official City
matters, prepare press releases, grant interviews, etc.
(d)   Knowledge, Skills and Abilities. The City Administrator shall have:
(1)    Knowledge of public administration principles, administrative management
principles and practices and city governmental processes and procedure;
(2)    The ability to communicate effectively in both oral and written form, to
coordinate autonomous organizational units toward common objectives, to plan
and establish viable short range goals to meet long range objectives, and to
develop and maintain effective working relationships with associates,
departmental supervisors, City officials and the general public;
(3)    The ability to plan viable City policies and procedures in consideration
of defined objectives and organizational needs;
(4)    Knowledge of budget development methods and techniques;
(5)    The ability to effectively control expenditures within established
budgetary guidelines;
(6)    The ability to prepare reports; and
(7)    The ability to deal effectively with the news media.
131.02 PARTICIPATION IN COOPERATIVE PURCHASING PROGRAMS.
   (a)    The City Administrator is hereby authorized to procure goods and
services through cooperative purchasing programs operated by the Ohio
Department of Transportation and Ohio Department of Administrative Services and
through joint purchasing programs operated by any national or state association
of political subdivisions in which the City of Defiance is now or may hereafter
be enrolled as a member, including, without limitation, the National Joint
Powers Alliance.
   (b)   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to bind the City to all
terms and conditions of the cooperative and joint purchasing programs in which
the City participates as prescribed by the Director of Transportation, Director
of Administrative Services or any national or state association of political
subdivisions of which the City is or may become a member.
   (c)   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to directly pay the vendor
of goods and services procured through cooperative and joint purchasing
programs in which the City participates.
   (d)   The City agrees to hold the Department of Transportation, Department
of Administrative Services and their Directors harmless against any claim or
dispute arising out of the award of a municipal procurement contract through a
cooperative purchasing program.
   (e)   The solicitation of bids shall not be required prior to the award of
any contract to supply goods or services procured through municipal
participation in a cooperative or joint purchasing program authorized by this
section. Procurement contracts awarded pursuant to this section shall be
approved in the manner required by Chapter
151 of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 7352. Passed 2-7-12.)
131.03 PRIVATE OCCUPATION OF MUNICIPAL RIGHTS-OF-WAY; PERMIT PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The City Administrator is hereby empowered to grant licenses
permitting private occupation of air-space over any lands within or beneath
streets, alleys and other municipal rights-of-way for purposes which are not
inconsistent with the public use of such lands.
   (b)   All licenses granted pursuant to the authority of this section shall
be revocable at will and without cause by the Municipality.
   (c)   All licenses granted pursuant to the authority of this section shall
be executed upon instruments approved by the Law Director and shall provide
that:
(1)   All improvements to be installed within, over or under a public right-of-
way be constructed in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the
City Engineer and inspected by appropriate municipal officials whenever such
inspection is provided for by ordinance, general law, building or fire
standards or is deemed necessary to assure compliance with the plans and
specifications approved by the City Engineer;
(2)   The installation of licensed improvements shall be performed at the
licensee's sole expense and that the licensee shall reimburse the Municipality
for any and all costs and expenses incurred as the result of making changes in
the public right-of-way to accommodate such improvements or to restore the
premises to the same or as good a condition as they were in prior to the
installation of the private improvements;
(3)   All licensed improvements installed within the right-of-way shall be
maintained and operated at the licensee's sole risk and expense and that the
Municipality shall not be accountable to the licensee for any damage to such
improvements which may be incurred incident to installation, operation,
maintenance, repair, relocation or renewal of public improvements within or
adjacent to the right-of-way;
(4)   All work incident to the construction, maintenance, replacement, repair,
renewal, or removal of licensed improvements shall be performed at times
satisfactory to and approved by the City Administrator so as to interfere as
little as possible with the public use of the right-of-way;
(5)   The licensee shall indemnify and hold the Municipality harmless against
any and all claims, demands, suits or actions to which the City may be
subjected, in whole or in part, by reason of the construction, installation,
maintenance, replacement, repair, renewal, presence or use of the licensed
improvements within the public right-of-way or by reason of the removal of such
improvements from the right-of-way, including attorney's fees and other
expenses of litigation reasonably incurred by the City in the defense thereof;
(6)   The licensee shall maintain one or more policies of Commercial General
Liability, Homeowners, Premises Liability or other insurance written upon forms
acceptable to the Law Director and underwritten by companies acceptable to the
Finance Director naming the Municipality as an additional insured thereunder
and providing for insurance coverage in amounts sufficient to assure that the
licensee maintains a capacity to pay not less than three hundred thousand
dollars ($300,000) in the event of an occurrence giving rise to a duty on the
part of the Licensee to indemnify the Municipality;
(7)   All privileges conferred by the license are personal to the licensee in
whose name the license is issued and not transferable by such licensee without
written consent of the Municipality;
(8)   All privileges conferred by the license are for an indeterminate period
of time, revocable with or without cause by the Municipality and that
revocation for cause may be predicated upon a finding by the City Administrator
that the presence, use, operation or maintenance of any private improvement
installed within the right-of-way is no longer consistent with public or any
proposed public use thereof;
(9)   The licensee shall remove all improvements permitted by the license
within ten days following revocation of the license for cause and within thirty
days following revocation of the license without cause.
   (d)   In the event any license issued pursuant to the authority of this
section is revoked and the licensee to whom such license has been granted fails
to remove the improvements from the public right-of-way within the time
permitted by the terms of the license, the Municipality shall be entitled to
remove the same without liability to the licensee for any damage occasioned
thereby and recover all costs reasonably incurred incident to such removal and
the restoration of the right-of-way to the same or as good a condition as it
was in prior to removal of the improvements.
(Ord. 5667. Passed 7-11-95.)
   (e)   Applications for licenses to occupy public rights-of-way shall be
filed on forms prescribed by the City Administrator. A processing fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall accompany each application and be deposited
to the General Fund to defray administrative expenses customarily incurred to
receive, review and act on the application. No rent or other charge shall be
levied or assessed as consideration for the use or occupation of a public
right-of- way pursuant to a license authorized by this section.
   (f)   All licenses granted pursuant to the authority of this section shall
be promptly recorded in miscellaneous or other appropriate records of the
Recorder of Defiance County by the City Administrator. In addition to the fee
provided by subsection (e) hereof, the licensee shall pay all costs and
expenses charged by the Recorder incident to the filing of the license for
record.
(Ord. 7106. Passed 12-15-09.)
   (g)   Nothing contained herein shall be construed to limit or restrict the
rights of any person to seek allowance of a license or the conveyance of a
greater interest in lands owned or controlled by the Municipality by
legislative action.
(Ord. 5667. Passed 7-11-95.)
131.04 COOPERATION WITH OHIO HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER.

without limitation, all loan applications and repayment agreements deemed
necessary or appropriate to such transactions.   
   (b)   The dedicated source of repayment of all funds borrowed from the Water
Pollution Control Loan Fund will be the Sewer Fund to include all existing cash
balances in the Sewer Capital Improvement and Water Pollution Control funds and

(Ord. 6578. Passed 7-12-05.)

(Ord. 8496. Passed 4-4-23.)

authorized by a resolution of Council.
(Ord. 4190. Passed 3-16-82.)
133.05 DAMAGE CLAIMS.
   (a)    Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning:
(1)    "Claimant" means the person seeking compensation.
(2)    "Damage claim" means a request for compensation from the City Treasury
by a claimant who alleges in his or her claim that he or she has suffered
damage to his or her person or property as a result of the act or omission of
the City or its officers or agents, for which he or she believes the City is
legally responsible.
(3)    "Moral claim" means the request for payment from the City Treasury by an
individual who requests compensation for damage from the City for harm
suffered, although the City is not legally responsible for the harm.
   (b)    Presentation of Claims. Any person who believes that he or she has
suffered harm as a result of an act or omission of the City or its officers or
agents, or who believes that he or she should be compensated by the City for a
harm he or she has suffered, shall present, in writing, a full account of the
facts and circumstances that give rise to the claim, list any individuals who
might have first-hand knowledge of these facts and circumstances and present
copies of any documents that might support the claim, together with the name,
address and telephone number of the claimant to the Department of Law.
   (c)    Investigation of Claims.
(1)    The principal officer of the department and/or division to which a claim
file has been referred shall add to the file any information the department
and/or division or its officers and employees may have regarding the claim and
shall forward the file to the Department of Law.
(2)    The Law Director or his or her assistant shall conduct an investigation
into the legal merits of the claim and form a recommendation for the
disposition of the claim. (Ord. 3890. Passed 2-5-80; Ord. 3907. Passed 3-4-80.)
   (d)    Disposition of Claims; Settlements.
      (1)    All claims in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall be
reported to Council in executive session.
      (2)   Settlements requiring the payment of more than two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00) from the City Treasury, authorized by Ordinance.
      (3)   The Law Director is authorized to settle damage claims without
express legislative authorization where:
         A.   His or her professional judgment on the substantive, evidentiary
and procedural issues and other practical considerations affecting the claim
indicates that it would be in the best interest of the City to reach a
negotiated settlement;
         B.   The settlement does not require the payment of more than two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) from the City Treasury and is
approved by a majority vote of the Board of Control documented in the Board
minutes; and
         C.   There are funds available in the Department account expressly
established for this purpose. (Ord. 7116. Passed 1-19-10.)
   (e)    Moral Claims; Settlements. Where the City is not legally responsible
for the damage on which a claimant bases his or her request for payment, or
where it is unlikely that the liability of the City could be established, but
the interests of justice might nevertheless be better served by the award of
some compensation at the public expense, Council shall direct the payment of
that award by legislation of record. No officer or employee of the City has the
power to represent or in any way bind the City for the award of a moral claim.
   (f)   Payment of Claims. Payment of claims shall be from funds and accounts
designated for that purpose. Payment will be made upon the execution of a
general release by the claimant.
(Ord. 3890. Passed 2-5-80; Ord. 3907. Passed 3-4-80.)
133.06 JOB DESCRIPTION FOR LAW DIRECTOR.
   (a)    Job Responsibilities. Under administrative direction, the Law
Director shall serve as Chief Legal Counsel to the Mayor, Council and
administrative offices, departments, commissions and boards of the City;
represent the City in court actions; prepare ordinances; prepare legal
documents; and perform other related duties as required.
   (b)    Qualifications. The Law Director shall have completed law school,
shall be licensed to practice law in the State and shall have been engaged in
the full-time practice of law continuously for a period of at least three
years.
   (c)    Illustrative Duties. The Law Director shall:
(1)    Plan, direct and administer the City's Law Department; act as Police
Prosecutor for the County; and act as advisor to the Police Department in
matters of law enforcement;
(2)    Provide legal advice and opinions for the Mayor, Council and its
committees, department/division heads and City boards and commissions,
regarding the conduct of City business; and conduct research of existing
statutes, ordinances and court decisions to aid in formulating legal opinions;
(3)    Represent the City during court actions, hearings with administrative
bodies and other litigation; prosecute offenders in the Municipal Court; and
monitor work of the Assistant City Attorney and other staff members;
(4)    Maintain authority and/or participate in management responsibilities and
decisions such as, but not limited to, discipline, hiring, promoting, adjusting
grievances, labor contract matters, assignments and employee evaluations, etc.;
(5)    Prepare contracts and other legal instruments involving City operations;
and prepare records, reports or other documentation, e.g. legal briefs, reports
regarding status of pending legal matters, etc.;
(6)    Attempt to settle or adjust claims by citizens involving the City or its
operations;
(7)    Supervise the drafting of legislation, revision and codification of
ordinances; and
(8)    Attend Council meetings and provide legal advice.
   (d)    Knowledge, Skills and Abilities. The Law Director shall have:
(1)   Knowledge of the field of law; of laws and regulations governing
municipal government; of local, State and Federal laws and court decisions
affecting municipalities; of organization functions and activities of municipal
government; of the Ohio Rules of Civil and Criminal Procedure; of
administrative management principles and practices; and of management theory;
and
(2)    The ability to communicate effectively through speech and writing, to
conduct in-depth research, to gather, analyze and interpret legal information,
to develop and maintain working relationships with associates, elected
officials, other professionals and the general public, to monitor or review the
work of others, to prepare and maintain accurate documentation, and to direct
and coordinate the work of other attorneys.

135.01  POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Finance Director shall demand and receive from the County Treasurer
taxes levied and assessments made and certified to the County Auditor by
authority of Council and placed by the County Auditor on the tax-list for
collection. The Director shall demand and receive, from persons authorized to
collect or required to pay them, moneys accruing to the City from judgments,
fines, penalties, forfeitures, licenses, costs taxed in the Municipal Court and
debts due the City. The Director shall disburse them on the order of the person
authorized by law or ordinance to issue such an order.
135.02 BOOKS AND ACCOUNTS; ADDITIONAL POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Finance Director shall keep the books of the City; shall keep an
accurate account of all moneys received by him or her, showing the amount and
the time when, from whom and on what account received, and of all disbursements
made by him or her, showing the amount and the time when, to whom and on what
account paid; and shall exhibit accurate statements of all property owned by
the City and the income derived therefrom and of all taxes and assessments. The
Director shall arrange his or her books so that the amount received and paid on
account of separate funds or specific appropriations shall be exhibited in
separate accounts. In addition to the ordinary duties, the Director shall have
the powers and perform the duties required by ordinances of the City not
inconsistent with this chapter and not incompatible with the nature of his or
her office.
135.03  QUARTERLY ACCOUNTS; ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Finance Director shall settle and account quarterly with Council and
when Council may, by resolution or ordinance, require. An annual estimate of
receipts and expenditures and of appropriation measures, and an annual report
on the financial condition and needs of the City, shall be given to Council by
the Mayor, pursuant to Section
3.05(4) of the City Charter and Section
129.02 of this Administrative Code.
135.04 AUTHORITY REGARDING CITY FUNDS.
   The Finance Director shall receive and disburse all funds of the City and
other funds as arise in or belong to any department or part of the City
Government.
135.05  DISTRIBUTION TO CITY BY COUNTY.
   On the first Monday of February and August in each year, the County
Treasurer shall pay over to the Finance Director all moneys belonging to the
City which were received by him or her to that date from taxes levied and
assessments made. Moneys for the City received from other sources shall be paid
over by the County Treasurer to the City on or before the tenth day of each
month following the receipt or collection of the funds.
135.06 DISPOSITION OF MONEYS AND PROPERTY UPON LEAVING OFFICE.
   At the expiration of his or her term of office, or on his or her resignation
or removal, the Finance Director shall deliver to his or her successor all
moneys, books, papers and other property in his or her possession as Director.
In the case of the death or incapacity of the Director, his or her legal
representative shall, in like manner, pay over and deliver the moneys and
property which were in the Director's hands to the person entitled to such
moneys or property.
135.07 DIRECTOR'S CLERK.
   The Finance Director is hereby authorized to hire a Clerk to aid him or her
in the execution of his or her duties.
135.08 INVESTMENT OF CITY FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the City which will not be
required to be used for six months or more, such moneys may, in lieu of being
deposited in a bank, be invested in accordance with Ohio R.C. 731.56 through
731.59. Investments so purchased shall be sold in accordance with Ohio R.C.
731.57.
(1980 Code §32.53)
135.09 SEAL.
   Council shall provide a seal for the Finance Director, in the center of
which shall be the name of the City and around the margin of which shall be the
words "Finance Director." An impression of the seal shall be affixed to all
transcripts, orders, certificates or other papers requiring authentication.
135.10 AUTHORITY REGARDING BIDS.
   When bids are required to be filed for the letting of contracts by the City
Administrator, the Finance Director shall attend and assist at the opening of
the bids and shall inspect them.
135.11 AUDITING ACCOUNTS; COLLECTION OF INDEBTEDNESS.
   At the end of each fiscal year, or more often if required by Council, the
Finance Director shall audit the accounts of all officers and departments. The
Director shall prescribe the form of accounts and reports to be rendered to the
Department of Finance and the form and method of keeping accounts by all other
departments. Subject to the powers and duties of the Auditor of State, the
Director shall inspect and revise the accounts and reports. On the death,
resignation, removal or expiration of the term of any officer, the Director
shall audit the account of the officer, and if the officer is found to be
indebted to the City, the Director shall immediately give notice to Council and
to the Director of Law, and the Director of Law shall proceed to collect the
indebtedness.
135.12 OVERDRAWING ON APPROPRIATIONS; PROOF REQUIRED FOR PAYMENT OF CLAIMS.
   The Finance Director shall not allow the amount set aside for any
appropriation to be overdrawn or allow a voucher to be paid unless sufficient
funds are actually in the City Treasury to the credit of the fund on which the
voucher is drawn. When any claim is presented to the Director, the Director may
require evidence that the amount is due, and for this purpose may summon any
agent, clerk or employee of the City, or any other person, and examine him or
her on oath or affirmation concerning the voucher or claim.
135.13 STATEMENTS OF RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURES FROM OFFICE AND DEPARTMENTS;
PERSONAL LIABILITY FOR UNAUTHORIZE PAYMENTS.
   On the first Monday of each month, detailed statements of the receipts and
expenditures of officers and departments for the preceding month shall be made
to the Finance Director by the heads of the departments. The Director shall
countersign each receipt before it is delivered to the person entitled to
receive it and shall charge himself or herself with that amount. If the
Director approves any voucher contrary to this chapter, the Director and his or
her sureties shall be individually liable for that amount.
135.14 CERTIFICATION OF ELECTION OF CERTAIN OFFICERS.
   (a)    The Finance Director shall certify the election of every officer of
the City having the power to discharge the duties of a judge of a county court,
to take the acknowledgment of deeds or to certify depositions or affidavits to
be used within the City to the Court of Common Pleas of the County, with the
date of the election and the time when the officer became legally qualified to
discharge the duties of the office. The certification shall be made within ten
days after qualification.
   (b)    The Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas shall record the certificates
in an appropriate record book. The same fees shall be allowed to the officers
certifying and recording them as are allowed under Ohio R.C. 2303.20(S) .
   (c) If the Director and the Clerk fail to perform their duties, they shall
be liable for all damages arising from such failure.
135.15  INCOME TAX DIVISION; BOARD OF REVIEW.
   (a)    Establishment of Division; Duties; Tax Commissioner. There is hereby
established an Income Tax Division within the Department of Finance, which
Division is hereby charged with the administration, collection and enforcement
of the income tax, the transient guest tax and any other tax that may be levied
by the City, except the real estate tax. The Division shall be under the
supervision of a Tax Commissioner and shall be composed of other personnel as
Council provides by ordinance.
   (b)    Board of Review. There is hereby established a Board of Review with
duties and powers as provided in Chapters
181 and
183 of this Administrative Code.
135.16 JOB DESCRIPTION FOR FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   (a)    Job Responsibilities. Under administrative direction, the Finance
Director shall direct and monitor the accounting, collection and custody of
funds; control disbursements; countersign bonds and notes; certify contracts
and other obligations for expenditures; participate in the investment of City
funds; and perform other related duties as required.
   (b)    Qualifications. The Finance Director shall have any combination of
training and work experience which indicates possession of the skills,
knowledge and abilities listed in subsection (d) hereof. An example of an
acceptable qualification for this position is as follows: Completion of post
secondary education in business, finance or other related areas and three years
of experience in municipal finance, including work in municipal accounting,
budgeting and purchasing, including the supervision of others, or equivalent.
   (c)    Illustrative Duties. The Finance Director shall:
(1)    Direct and monitor the accounting, collection and custody of City funds;
and provide instruction for clerks, the Tax Commissioner and the Utility
Billing Supervisor, as necessary;
(2)    Direct and monitor the personnel records and payroll system;
(3)    Participate in management responsibilities and decisions, such as, but
not limited to, recommending discipline, hiring and promotions, adjusting
grievances and other labor contract administrative matters and assignments; and
evaluate employee performance levels;
(4)    Maintain a cash control ledger of City funds; coordinate investments and
cash control to ensure the City's ability to meet expense obligations; and
ensure that expenditures do not exceed appropriations;
(5)    Supervise accounts payable functions; approve all disbursements; certify
all purchase orders and coding, and certify City contracts as to availability
of funds;
(6)    Process legal documents necessary for the issuance of notes or bonds;
maintain a bond register; and properly retire all debt;
(7)    Conduct research and prepare various records, reports and other related
documentation, e.g. the annual State financial report, the annual County budget
report, monthly financial reports, budget books, bond and note indebtedness
statements, etc.;
(8)    Act as data processing supervisor for all divisions; select appropriate
financial and personnel systems software; and operate the computer in payroll,
accounts payable, budgeting and general ledger;
(9)    Invest all City funds, keep an investment register and properly credit
interest;
(10)    Communicate with Council members, Council Finance Committee members,
bond counselors, bank and savings and loan officials and other related
professionals regarding City finances, treasury investments, depository
contracts, bond and note issues, etc.; and
(11)    Serve on the Board of Control and assist in developing and interpreting
policies for all divisions.
   (d)   Knowledge, Skills and Abilities. The Finance Director shall have:
(1)    Knowledge of management practices and principles, personnel management,
public finance, public accounting, codes, ordinances and other regulations
governing public finances, city government structure and process, computer
operations, computer software, public relations and investment strategies; and
(2)    The ability to direct and coordinate activities of others; exercise
considerable independent judgment; communicate effectively through speech and
writing; collect, analyze and interpret data; identify existing or potential
problem areas and formulate corrective measures; develop and maintain working
relationships with other City employees, community officials and other related
professionals; prepare and maintain accurate documentation; review work of
others to ensure compliance with established standards; utilize computer
hardware; and select and utilize computer software to meet financial and
personnel reporting needs.
135.17 INDIGENT DRIVERS ALCOHOL TREATMENT FUND.
   (a)    There is hereby created an Indigent Drivers Alcohol Treatment Fund,
for the purpose of proper accounting of fine moneys received relating to
alcohol related traffic offenses.
   (b)    Funds so received shall be disbursed according to the regulations set
forth in Ohio R.C. 4511.19(M).
   (c)    The Finance Director shall select an appropriate financial
institution in the City in which to establish said Fund. (Ord. 5207. Passed 9-
18-90.)
135.18  PETTY CASH FUNDS.
   (a)    Petty cash funds shall be maintained in the following amounts:
Municipal Court             $100.00
Utility Billing Office      600.00
Engineering                 100.00
Building Inspection         100.00
Income Tax                  200.00
Finance Departmental Office 200.00
Fire                        200.00
Water                       100.00
Water Pollution Control     100.00
Police                      200.00
Parks and Recreation        100.00
Cable Television            100.00
Streets                     100.00
Law Departmental Office     100.00
TOTAL                       $2300.00
   (b)    The Finance Director is directed to provide for said funds from the
operating budgets of the corresponding divisions and departments.
(Ord. 5903. Passed 2-3-98.)
135.19 COPIES OF PUBLIC DOCUMENTS; FEES.
   (a)   The charge to be levied for the reproduction of public documents
duplicated by conventional xerographic methods on eight and one-half inch by
fourteen inch and smaller plain paper stock shall be five cents (5¢) per page.
   (b)   The City Administrator is directed to determine the actual cost of
replicating documents that are maintained in formats larger than eight and one-
half inches by fourteen inches, that cannot be reproduced by conventional black
and white xerographic methods or that cannot be reproduced on plain paper and
shall require the prepayment of such costs as a condition to the replication of
such documents.
   (c)   Nothing contained in subsections (a) or (b) hereof shall be construed
to require the imposition of a charge for the replication of documents that are
presently furnished without charge pursuant to ordinance, rule of Council or
order of the Board of Control.
(Ord. 6033. Passed 6-8-99.)

137.01  ESTABLISHMENT OF DIVISIONS.
   (a)    There is hereby established the following divisions within the
Department of Service and Safety:
(1)    The Division of Building Inspection;
(2)    The Division of Engineering;
(3)    The Division of Parks and Recreation;
(4)    The Division of Streets;
(5)    The Division of Water;
(6)    The Division of Water Pollution Control;
(7)    The Division of Police; and
(8)    The Division of Fire.
   (b)    Council may establish additional divisions as necessary and may
determine the number of superintendents, deputies, inspectors, engineers,
clerks, laborers and other persons necessary for the execution of the work and
the performance of the duties of the Department.
137.02 SUPERVISION OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS.
   The City Administrator shall supervise the improvement and repair of
streets, avenues, alleys, lands, lanes, squares, wharves, docks, landings,
market houses, bridges, viaducts, aqueducts, sidewalks, playgrounds, sewers,
drains, ditches, culverts, ship channels, streams and watercourses, the
lighting, sprinkling and cleaning of public places and the construction of
public improvements and public works, except as otherwise provided in this
chapter.
(ORC 735.02; 1980 Code Sec. 33.13)
137.03  MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC UTILITIES AND PROPERTY.
   The City Administrator shall manage Municipal water, lighting, heating,
power, garbage and other undertakings of the City, market houses, cemeteries,
crematories, sewage disposal plants and farms. The City Administrator shall
make and preserve surveys, maps, plans, drawings and estimates. The City
Administrator shall supervise the construction and have charge of the
maintenance of public buildings and other property of the City not otherwise
provided for in this chapter. The City Administrator shall have the management
of all other matters provided by Council in connection with the public service
of the City.
(ORC 735.02; 1980 Code §33.14)
137.04 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF WATERWORKS.
   The City Administrator shall manage, conduct and control the waterworks of
the City, furnish supplies of water and appoint necessary officers and agents.
137.05 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF SEWERAGE SYSTEM.
   The City Administrator shall manage, conduct and control the sewerage system
and sewage pumping, treatment and disposal works and shall appoint the
necessary officers and agents for these purposes.
137.06 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF CEMETERIES.
   The City Administrator shall take possession and charge of, and have entire
management, control and regulation of, public burial grounds and cemeteries
located in or belonging to the City, subject to its ordinances. The City
Administrator shall direct all improvements and embellishments of the grounds
and lots, protect and preserve them and, subject to the approval of Council,
appoint necessary superintendents, employees and agents and determine their
terms of office and the amount of their compensation.
(ORC 759.09; 1980 Code §33.18)
CHAPTER 139
Police Division
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The City enters into Agreements with Local No. 166, Defiance
Police Officers Association (AFL-CIO), concerning compensation and conditions
of employment for members of the Police Division. Copies of the latest relevant
legislation and Agreement may be obtained, at cost, from the City
Administrator.
139.01    Composition.
139.02    Powers of Chief of Police.
139.03    Private police.
139.04    Auxiliary Police Unit.
139.05    Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund.
139.06    Acceptance of seized and forfeited property; Law Enforcement Trust
Fund.
139.07   Chief of Police to charge service fees taxable as court costs.
139.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Selection of Police Chief and Assistant Chief - see CHTR.
6.05(b)
Civil service - see CHTR.
6.05(a),
7.01
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. 737.05 et seq.
 
139.01 COMPOSITION.
   In addition to the City Administrator, the Chief of Police and such
emergency patrolmen as may be appointed by the Mayor, the Police Division shall
be composed of the following officers and other members:
(a)    An Assistant Chief of Police;
(b)    Four lieutenants;
(c)    Four sergeants-technicians;
(d)    Twenty-two patrolmen.
      (Ord. 8350. Passed 10-26-21.)
139.02  POWERS OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)    The Chief of Police shall have the exclusive control of all patrolmen
and other officers and employees in the Police Division and the Auxiliary
Police Unit under general rules and regulations prescribed for such Division
and such Auxiliary Unit by the City Administrator.
   (b)    Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.041, the Chief of Police or the Assistant
Chief is hereby designated as the Police Division officer who may authorize
members of the Division to provide police protection to any county, municipal
corporation or township in the State.
(ORC 737.06; 1980 Code §33.24; Res. 1999. Passed 8-7-84.)
139.03 PRIVATE POLICE.
   Private police officers performing special duties for the benefit and at the
expense of private persons or corporations may be commissioned by the Chief of
Police, with the approval of the City Administrator, upon a showing of
necessity by the persons or corporations. Applications for a commission as a
private police officer shall not be considered by the Chief of Police or
approved by the City Administrator until the applicant has paid to the Clerk of
Council a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for an original commission or a
yearly renewal fee of five dollars ($5.00). The fees shall not be refunded if
the commission is denied or revoked. Private police officers shall be subject
to the orders of the Chief of Police and bound by the rules and regulations
prescribed by the City Administrator and shall give bond to the City in the sum
of one thousand dollars ($1,000). The commission of a private police officer
shall be subject to revocation by the Chief of Police for cause.
   No person shall perform the duties of a private police officer without
obtaining a commission as a private police officer.
139.04 AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)    Establishment. An Auxiliary Police Unit is hereby established within
the Police Division of the City.
(1980 Code §33.31)
   (b)    City Administrator to be Executive Head. The City Administrator shall
be the executive head of the Auxiliary Police Unit and shall make all
appointments and removals of auxiliary police officers, subject to any general
regulations prescribed by Council by ordinance. The City Administrator shall
prescribe rules and regulations for the organization, training, administration,
control and conduct of the Auxiliary Police Unit.
(1980 Code §33.32)
   (c)    Members Not Eligible for Relief or Pension. Members of the Auxiliary
Police Unit are not eligible for membership in the police relief and pension
fund under Ohio R.C. Chapter 742.
(1980 Code §33.33)
   (d)    Members Not in Classified Service. Members of the Auxiliary Police
Unit shall not be in the classified service of the City.
(1980 Code §33.34)
   (e)    Compensation. All services performed by auxiliary police officers
shall be on a voluntary basis and within the City. An auxiliary police officer
shall be paid one dollar ($1.00) annually.
(1980 Code §33.35)
   (f)    Authority of Chief. The Chief of Police shall have such powers with
respect to the Auxiliary Police Unit as are granted in Section
139.02 .
(1980 Code §33.36)
   (g)    Nonliability. Neither the City, an agent or representative of the
City, an officer appointed under this section, nor any person, receiver,
trustee or other agent who, in good faith, executes any executive order, rule
or regulation promulgated pursuant to this section, shall be liable for injury
or damage sustained to persons or property as the direct and proximate result
of the action.
(1980 Code §33.37)
139.05 LAW ENFORCEMENT MANDATORY DRUG FINE FUND.
   (a)    The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to accept cash from the
mandatory drug fines imposed on convicted drug offenders in accordance with
Ohio R.C. 2925.03(J) and (K).
   (b)    The Mayor shall place all cash received pursuant to subsection (a)
hereof into a special Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund with the Finance
Director to be used solely for Division of Police law enforcement efforts
pertaining to drug offenses. Such Fund shall be separate and apart from any
other special fund previously established.
(Ord. 4823. Passed 9-1-87.)
139.06 ACCEPTANCE OF SEIZED AND FORFEITED PROPERTY; LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)    The Mayor is authorized to accept cash, vehicles and other tangible
personal property forfeited to the Municipality or Division of Police by any
order, judgment or decree issued by a court of record of the United States or
any state, territory or possession of the United States pursuant to laws
governing the disposition of property seized in the course of a law enforcement
investigation. Any acceptance of real estate forfeited to the Municipality or
Police Division by the terms of any such order, judgment or decree shall be
accepted only by ordinance of Council and the judicial order, judgment or
decree shall not be deemed to convey title to the Municipality or any Municipal
agency prior to the effective date of the ordinance accepting the conveyance.
   (b)   The Mayor is directed to place all cash received pursuant to
subsection (a) hereof into the special purpose Law Enforcement Trust Fund
created by Ordinances 4824 and 4825 to be used solely for law enforcement
purposes. Such Fund shall be maintained separate and apart from all other
Municipal funds and shall be administered by the Finance Director in accordance
with general laws governing the administration of special purpose funds.
   (c)   All vehicles and property, forfeited to the Municipality or Division
of Police pursuant to subsection (a) hereof shall be used solely for law
enforcement purposes or sold in a manner authorized by general ordinance.
Proceeds from the sale of any and all such property shall be deposited to the
Law Enforcement Trust Fund to be used solely for law enforcement purposes.
(Ord. 7051. Passed 6-16-09.)
139.07 CHIEF OF POLICE TO CHARGE SERVICE FEES TAXABLE AS COURT COSTS.
   (a)   When an officer or employee of the Police Division performs a service
enumerated in Ohio R.C. 311.17, the Chief of Police shall charge a fee in the
amount provided by Ohio R.C. 311.17 for performance of the service by the
Sheriff on the date the service is rendered.
   (b)   When an officer or employee of the Police Division performs a service
for which a fee has been established by a section of the Ohio Revised Code
other than Ohio R.C. 311.17 or for which a fee has been established by rule of
court, the Chief of Police shall charge a fee computed in accordance with such
statutory provision or rule of court.
   (c)   In the event of a conflict between fees computed in accordance with
subsection (a) and subsection (b) hereof, the Chief of Police shall charge in
accordance with subsection (b) hereof.
   (d)   When an officer or employee of the Police Division performs a service
for which a fee is to be charged pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) hereof, the
Chief of Police shall add any extraordinary expenses actually incurred by the
Police Division in rendering the service, including applicable legal fees and
overtime expenses, to the amount charged.
   (e)   All fees charged pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) hereof and all
expenses charged in accordance with subsection (d) hereof shall be submitted to
the Clerk of Court in which the civil, criminal or traffic action or proceeding
is pending and shall be taxed as costs in the case for collection and payment
in accordance with general law.
(Ord. 7015. Passed 1-13-09.)
139.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
139.03 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
CHAPTER 141
Fire Division
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The City enters into Agreements with Local No. 918,
International Association of Firefighters (AFL-CIO) concerning compensation and
conditions of employment for members of the Fire Division. Copies of the latest
relevant legislation and Agreement may be obtained, at cost, from the City
Administrator.
   The City also enters into mutual-aid agreements, from time to time, with
various municipalities for fire and emergency rescue ambulance services. Copies
of the latest relevant legislation may be obtained from the City Administrator.
141.01    Composition.
141.02    Duties generally.
141.03    Powers of Fire Chief.
141.04    Authority of Council.
141.05    Investigation of fires.
141.06    Arrest powers; examination of buildings.
141.07    Schooling of officers and fire-fighters.   
141.08    Emergency fire-fighters.
141.09    Bureau of Fire Prevention.
141.10    Fire and Rescue Service Donation Fund.
141.11    Fire damaged structures; payment of insurance claims.
141.12    Issuance of citations for parking in fire lanes.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Selection of Chief and Assistant Chief - see CHTR.
6.05(b)
Civil service - see CHTR.
6.05(a),
7.01
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. 737.05 et seq.
 
141.01 COMPOSITION.
   In addition to the City Administrator, the Chief of the Fire Division, the
part-time and auxiliary firefighters as may be appointed by the Chief and
emergency firefighters as may be appointed by the Mayor, the Fire Division
shall be composed of the following officers and other members:
   (a)   One Assistant Chief;
   (b)   One Battalion Chief (city-wide safety);
   (c)   Three captains;
   (d)   Three lieutenants; and
   (e)   Twenty-one firefighters.
(Ord. 8057. Passed 9-11-18.)
141.02 DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Fire Division shall protect the lives and property of the people in case
of fire and shall perform such other duties as Council, by ordinance,
prescribes.
(ORC 737.11; 1980 Code Sec. 33.22)
141.03  POWERS OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Fire Division shall have exclusive control of all fire-
fighters and other officers and employees in the Division under general rules
and regulations prescribed by the City Administrator.
(ORC 737.09; 1980 Code Sec. 33.39)
   
141.04 AUTHORITY OF COUNCIL.
   Council may establish all necessary regulations to guard against fires and
to protect the property and lives of the residents of the City against
resulting damage and accidents and for that purpose may establish and maintain
a Fire Division, provide for the establishment and organization of fire engine
and hose companies, establish the hours of labor of the members of the Division
and provide rules and regulations for its government as deemed necessary and
proper.
(ORC 737.21; 1980 Code Sec. 33.40)
141.05 INVESTIGATION OF FIRES.
   The Mayor may invest any officer of the Fire Division or the Police Division
with the power, and impose on him or her the duty, to be present at all fires,
investigate their cause, examine witnesses and compel their attendance and the
production of books and papers and do and perform all other acts as may be
necessary to the effective discharge of such duties.
141.06 ARREST POWERS; EXAMINATION OF BUILDINGS.
   The officer designated in Section
141.05 shall have the power to administer oaths, make arrests and enter and
examine any building which, in his or her opinion, is endangered by fire. He or
she shall report his or her proceedings to Council at such times as may be
required.
(ORC 737.27; 1980 Code Sec. 33.42)
   
141.07  SCHOOLING OF OFFICERS AND FIRE-FIGHTERS.
   The City Administrator and/or the Fire Chief may send any of the officers
and fire-fighters of the Fire Division to schools of instruction designed to
promote the efficiency of fire-fighters. If duly authorized in advance, the
City Administrator shall pay their necessary expenses from the funds used for
the maintenance and operation of the Division.
141.08 EMERGENCY FIRE-FIGHTERS.
   In case of a riot or other emergency, the Mayor may appoint additional fire-
fighters and officers for temporary service in the Fire Division. Such
personnel need not be in the classified list of the Division. The additional
persons shall be employed only for the time during which the emergency exists.
(ORC 737.10; 1980 Code Sec. 33.44)
141.09  BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION.
   There is hereby established a Bureau of Fire Prevention under the
supervision of the Chief of the Fire Division. The Chief may detail members of
the Division as inspectors as he or she from time to time deems necessary. The
Chief shall recommend to the Board of Control the employment of technical
inspectors who, if they are to be full-time permanent employees, shall be
selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position.
The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the Division. The
Bureau shall enforce the Fire Prevention Code of the City, being Part Fifteen
of these Codified Ordinances.
141.10 FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE DONATION FUND.
   (a)    Council hereby authorizes the establishment of a separate fund which
shall be known as the Fire and Rescue Service Donation Fund. This Fund shall be
used to accept donations from residents who want to make a contribution to the
Fire Division. Moneys in this Fund shall be used for the purchase and
maintenance of equipment; for the training of personnel; and for the purposes
of fire-fighting, fire prevention, rescue service, emergency transfer service
and the handling of chemical spills and dangerous and hazardous materials.
   (b)    The Finance Director shall select an appropriate financial
institution in the City in which to set up the Fund's moneys and shall invest
such moneys in any manner approved by State law for municipal funds.
   (c)    The Fire Chief is hereby authorized to make withdrawals from the Fund
for any expense or purchase that, in his or her judgment, is necessary for the
Fire Division and consistent with the purposes set forth in subsection (a)
hereof. All withdrawals shall be in accordance with then existing City rules
and ordinances for vouchers, purchase orders and competitive bidding. (Ord.
4281. Passed 10-19-82.)
141.11 FIRE DAMAGED STRUCTURES; PAYMENT OF INSURANCE CLAIMS.
   (a)    Procedures. The City hereby authorizes the procedure described in
Ohio R.C. 3929.86(C) and (D) to be implemented, whereby no insurance company
doing business in the State shall pay a claim of a named insured for fire to a
structure located within the City unless the applicable provisions of Ohio R.C.
3929.86 are fully complied with. The Fire Chief is hereby designated as the
officer authorized to carry out the duties of Ohio R.C. 3929.86.
(Ord. 4331. Passed 3-15-83.)
   
   (b)    Escrow Account.
(1)    Council hereby authorizes the Finance Director to set up an escrow
account at an appropriate financial institution for the purpose of holding any
moneys received for fire damaged structures pursuant to subsection (a) hereof.
(2)    The Finance Director, upon the recommendation of the Fire Chief, shall
make withdrawals from the account consistent with subsection (a) hereof and
Ohio R.C. 3929.86. All withdrawals shall be in accordance with existing City
rules and ordinances for vouchers, purchase orders and competitive bidding
         (Ord. 4330. Passed 3-15-83.)
141.12  ISSUANCE OF CITATIONS FOR PARKING IN FIRE LANES.
   (a)    The Fire Division is hereby authorized and empowered to issue parking
tickets for prohibited parking in fire lanes within the City.
   (b)    The Chief or Assistant Chief of the Fire Division shall designate the
appropriate personnel within their Division to enforce said fire lane parking
violations.
(Ord. 5101. Passed 11-7-89.)
