1337.01 PURPOSE; OBJECTIVES.
   (a)    The purpose of this chapter is to promote public health, safety and
welfare by establishing reasonable regulations governing the size, character,
location and structural integrity of signs and other advertising structures.
This chapter is enacted to promote:
(1)    Vehicular and pedestrian safety by prohibiting signage that obstructs
the view of or distracts attention from traffic control devices;
(2)    Vehicular and pedestrian safety by eliminating visual obstructions
resulting from signage located adjacent to or over public rights-of-way;
(3)    Public safety by establishing design and maintenance standards for
advertising structures that reduce the risk of fire, collapse and fragmentation
and by providing for the inspection and removal of advertising structures that
have become unsafe;
(4)    Public safety by prohibiting signs that interfere with fire fighting and
rescue efforts;
(5)    Economic well-being by permitting commercial enterprises to use
advertising structures of sufficient size to fulfill communicative needs while
prohibiting excessively large structures and sign competition that tends to
depreciate the value of adjacent properties; and,
(6)    Community development consistent with the City's 2010 Land Use Plan and
the maintenance of high quality land use districts for all zoned uses by
prohibiting signs that are inappropriate to their environs.
   (b)    All Ordinances are to be construed in favor of promoting vigorous
political debate and accommodation of the rights of residents and visitors to
speak freely. The provisions of this chapter shall be uniformly enforced
without regard to the content of any advertising message or the identity of the
proponent of that message.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.02 SCOPE; CONFLICTS.
   The provisions of this chapter supplement building standards established by
the Ohio Building Code and Ordinances pertaining to zoning and the regulation
of business enterprises. In the event of a conflict, the more restrictive
standard shall apply.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.03 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    As used in this chapter, the terms: "Sign" "Closed Sign" "Ground
Sign" "Marquee Sign', “Open Sign”, "Portable Sign" "Projecting Sign" "Roof
Sign" "Temporary Sign" and "Wall Sign" shall be accorded the meaning attributed
to them by the Ohio Building Code.
   (b)    "Abandoned Sign" means a sign that no longer carries a readable
message or that directs the public to a location where goods or services
advertised are no longer available.
   (c)    "Area" means the area encompassed by the smallest circle, ellipse,
triangle, rectangle, trapezoid, pentagon, hexagon or octagon that completely
contains a sign, including any perimeter frame, but excluding all supports or
uprights on which the sign may be placed. Where a sign consists of individual
letters, words or symbols, the area of each component shall be computed and
total sign area shall be computed as the sum of the areas encompassed by the
individual components.
   (d)    "Billboard" means any sign advertising, identifying, or directing
attention to any product, service, entertainment, or commercial activity that
is not offered on the lot on which the sign is located.
   (e)    "Building Frontage" means the length of any exterior wall of a
building facing a public right of way. In a building that is subdivided by a
party wall or walls into spaces with separate exterior entrances, “Building
Frontage” means the length of the exterior wall or walls of the building facing
the public right-of-way measured to the center of the party wall or walls. In
the event a building or building unit fronts more than one public right-of-way,
the "Building Frontage" shall be separately calculated for each facade.
   (f)    "Erect" means to construct, assemble, install, alter or relocate a
sign and includes the acts of attaching, affixing, hanging, suspending,
painting and placement of signs, but does not include repair or replacement of
changeable copy, repainting, cleaning or other maintenance that does not
involve the repair or replacement of foundation elements, structural members or
electrical components.
   (g)    "Flag" means any sign of cloth or similar material anchored along one
side and displayed from a single pole, either freestanding or attached to a
building, displaying the ensign, emblem or insignia of a governmental,
corporate, educational, or athletic entity or other organization.
   (h)    "Frontage" means "lot frontage" as defined by Section 1141.07 and
measured in accordance with Chapter 1141 of the Codified Ordinances.
   (i)    "Illuminated Sign" means any sign that is illuminated by any internal
or external light source other than non-reflected natural daylight or ambient
public street lighting.
   (j)    "Obscene Sign" means a sign that depicts or otherwise communicates
matter deemed "obscene" or "harmful to juveniles" under standards established
by the Ohio Revised Code.
   (k)    "Person" means any individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership, limited liability corporation or other legal entity.
   (l)    "Vehicular Sign" means any sign attached or applied to or painted on
a vehicle for the primary purpose of advertising or directing attention to a
product, service, entertainment, or commercial activity but does not include
words, graphics or other communication that serves to identify the vehicle as
one ordinarily and routinely used and operated in the course of the business
advertised.
   (m)    "Window Sign" means a non-illuminated sign painted on, applied to or
installed inside a window for viewing from outside the premises but does not
include window displays of merchandise.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.04 PROHIBITIONS.
   (a)    No sign shall be erected on public property or within any public
right of way except by governmental authorities in the discharge of a
governmental function or pursuant to a license to occupy the right-of-way
granted in accordance with Section
131.03;
   (b)    No Ground Sign shall be erected within 10 feet of any public right-
of-way or within 150 feet of any other Ground Sign located adjacent to the same
side of the same public right-of- way;
   (c)    No sign shall be erected in any place that interferes with the
ventilation system of a building or impedes access to any fire hydrant or
standpipe, fire extinguisher or fire alarm or to any door, window, fire escape
or other means of egress from a building;
   (d)    No sign exhibiting animated graphic illustrations, flashing or
rotating lights or mirrors, banners, pennants, ribbons, streamers, spinners or
similar devices that move or change appearance shall be erected in any place
that is visible from a public right-of-way or from publicly or privately owned
lands customarily open to vehicular traffic. This paragraph does not prohibit
the erection of public service devices that display the date, time, temperature
or news information in a manner that does not imitate or distract attention
from traffic control devices;
   (e)    No illuminated sign shall be erected in any place that results in
objectionable brightness or glare in any residential premises or on any public
right of way.
   (f)    No billboard shall be erected.
   (g)    Abandon Signs, Obscene Signs, Portable Signs, Roof Signs and
Vehicular Signs are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and are prohibited.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.05 ZONING RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)    Signs exempted from permit requirements by Section
1337.09 may be erected in any zoning District.
   (b)    Signs identifying the occupant of the premises on which the sign is
located, or advertising any product, service or entertainment offered at that
location, shall be permitted as a business use accessory to the commercial,
industrial, educational, religious, institutional or other activity conducted
on the premises in all zoning districts other than SR, R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-4.
   (c)    Signs identifying multifamily housing facilities shall be permitted
as a business use accessory to the operation of apartment or condominium
complexes in districts zoned R-3 and signs identifying mobile home parks shall
be permitted as a business use accessory to the operation of a mobile home park
in districts zoned R-4.
   (d)    Signs identifying the principal entrances to a subdivision shall be
permitted in districts zoned SR, R-1, R-2 and R-3.
   (e)    In reviewing applications seeking approval of the establishment of a
land use permitted as a Special Exception, the Board of Zoning and Building
Appeals shall consider the necessity of signage accessory to the proposed use
and the requirements and conditions imposed by the Board pursuant to Section
1165.07 may include restrictions on the placement, height, dimensions,
luminosity and other characteristics of signage permitted as accessory to the
land use.
   (f)    The Board of Zoning and Building Appeals may grant a Special
Exception permitting the erection of one or more signs identifying the
occupant, or advertising products, services or entertainments offered by the
occupant, of lands located in an SR, R-1, R-2 or R-3 District and lawfully used
for commercial, industrial, educational, religious, institutional or other
purposes.
   (g)    In reviewing applications for the allowance of a Special Exception
pursuant to subsections (d) or (e) hereof, the Board shall consider the
communicative needs of the applicant and the placement, height, illumination,
noise of operation, size, structural integrity and permanency of the proposed
sign in relation to:
(1)    The public right of way and potential interference with vehicular or
pedestrian traffic; and,
(2)    The impact of the sign on the use and development of adjacent property,
including, but not solely determined by, aesthetic considerations.
         (Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.06 HEIGHT RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)    Ground Signs shall not exceed 5 feet in height unless the lowest
horizontal element is elevated more than 9 feet above the adjacent grade.
   (b)    Except as provided by subsection (c) hereof, Elevated Ground Signs
shall not exceed 30 feet in height.
   (c)    Elevated Ground Signs identifying premises offering food, lodging or
automotive services and oriented for view by motorists traveling on a limited
access highway shall not exceed 50 feet in height.
   (d)    Marquee Signs shall have a minimum vertical clearance of 10 feet
above the grade of any adjacent sidewalk and a minimum vertical clearance of 14
feet above the grade of any driveway or other area open to vehicular traffic. A
Marquee Sign mounted above a marquee or canopy shall not extend above the
roofline of the building to which the marquee or canopy is attached.
   (e)    Wall Signs shall not extend above the top of the wall to which they
are attached.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.07 AREA LIMITATIONS.
   (a)    The maximum area of each face of a Ground Sign shall be the lesser of
1.5 square feet for each foot of frontage or 250 square feet.
   (b)    The maximum area of a Marquee Sign shall be the greater of 1.5 square
feet for each foot of building frontage or the perimeter of the three exposed
sides of the marquee, canopy or other supporting structure, measured in feet,
multiplied by 5 square feet.
   (c)    Except as provided by subsections (d) and (e) hereof, the maximum
area of a Wall Sign or Projecting Sign shall be 1.5 square feet for each foot
of building frontage.
   (d)    The maximum area of a Wall Sign or Projecting Sign attached to a
building that is located in a B-3 or B-4 District and more than 200 feet from
the principal public right-of-way from which the sign is intended to be viewed
shall be 1.75 square feet for each foot of building frontage.
   (e)    The maximum area of a Wall Sign or Projecting Sign attached to a
building that is located in a B-3 or B-4 District and more than 400 feet from
the principal public right-of-way from which the sign is intended to be viewed
shall be 2.00 square feet for each foot of building frontage.
   (f)    The aggregate area of all signs located on any one lot or parcel of
land, including temporary signs and signs exempted from permit requirements,
shall not exceed 2 square feet for each foot of frontage.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
1337.08 VARIANCES.
   The Board of Zoning and Building Appeals may grant variances from the height
and area requirements of Sections
1337.06 and
1337.07 where unique physical characteristics of, or character of land uses
adjacent to, a property on which a non-conforming sign is proposed to be
located demonstrate that literal application of the requirements of said
sections will not further the purposes for which this chapter has been enacted
or will result in an undue hardship on the applicant and that the restriction
on the applicant's use of the property is not justified by any corresponding
benefit to public health, safety or welfare. In reviewing applications for a
variance, the Board shall conduct its proceedings in the manner provided by the
Zoning Code and shall consider the following factors in addition to those
required by Section
1165.06(a)(2):
(1)    The extent the applicant requires the variance for the effective
communication of the sign's message;
(2)   Harmony of the proposed sign's use or dimensions with the building or
property on which it is to be located;
(3)    The degree to which the applicant's request departs from the height,
set- back, dimensional and use restrictions of this chapter;
(4)    Whether the variance would increase the risk that the vision of
vehicular traffic would be obstructed; and
(5)    Whether granting a variance would be substantially detrimental to the
district or adjacent properties in which the sign is to be located.
   The Board may condition the allowance of a variance on such conditions as it
deems necessary to assure fulfillment of the objectives of this chapter.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
 
1337.09 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    Except as provided in this section, no person shall erect any sign
without first obtaining a Sign Permit from the Building and Zoning
Commissioner.
 
   (b)    No permit shall be required for the erection of a sign expressly
exempted from the permit requirements of the Ohio Building Code.
 
   (c)    No permit shall be required for the erection of:
(1)   A non-illuminated temporary ground sign less than 12 square feet in area
and 5 feet in height;
(2)   A window sign that does not exceed 10 square feet in area and does not
cover more than 25% of area of the window;
(3)   A sign that is an integral part of the original construction of a vending
machine, fuel pump or similar device;
(4)   A flag not exceeding 20 square feet in area or 5 feet in length and
located entirely within the boundaries of the lot or parcel on which it is
flown;
(5)   A cornerstone incorporated into a building and displaying only the name
of the building, building owner, architect, contractor, dates of construction,
brief dedication and similar historical information;
(6)   A plaque or nameplate not exceeding 3 square feet in area that is
permanently affixed to a building as a wall sign and displays only the name of
the building, address of the building and name of the occupant or occupants of
the building;
(7)   Monuments and markers within cemeteries;
(8)   Letters and numbers less than 6 inches in height identifying the address
of any structure.
 
   (d)    Applications for the issuance of a permit shall be made on forms
prescribed by the Building and Zoning Commissioner and shall require the
disclosure of all information necessary to demonstrate compliance with all
applicable provisions of the Ohio Building Code, the Zoning Code and this
chapter.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
 
1337.10 SIGNS AND OTHER ADVERTISING STRUCTURES IN THE CENTRAL BUSINESS
DISTRICT.
   (a)    The provisions of this section supplement the Ohio Building Code and
Sections
1337.01 to
1337.09 with respect to signs erected in the Central Business District. In the
event of a conflict, the more restrictive standards shall apply.
 
   (b)    Central Business District Defined. As used in this section, "Central
Business District" means the area bounded by:
The water's edge on the west bank of the Auglaize River between the centerline
of Hopkins Street and the confluence of the Auglaize and Maumee Rivers;
The water's edge on the south bank of the Maumee River between the confluence
of the Auglaize and Maumee Rivers and the point at which the centerline of
Jackson Avenue would intersect the water's edge if extended north of the
intersection of Jackson Avenue and First Street;
The centerline of Jackson Avenue between the points of intersection with the
water's edge on the south bank of the Maumee River and the centerline of
Thurston Street;
The centerline of Thurston Street between the points of intersection with the
centerlines of Jackson Avenue and Clinton Street;
The centerline of Clinton Street between the points of intersection with the
centerlines of Thurston Street and Arabella Street; .
The centerline of Arabella Street between the points of intersection with
centerlines of Clinton Street and Jefferson Avenue;
The centerline of Jefferson Avenue between the points of intersection with the
centerlines of Clinton Street and Fifth Street;
The centerline of Fifth Street between the points of intersection with the
centerlines of Jefferson Avenue and Washington Avenue;
The centerline of Washington Avenue between the points of intersection with the
centerlines of Fifth Street and Hopkins Street; and,
The centerline of Hopkins Avenue between the points of intersection with the
centerline of Washington Avenue and the water's edge on the west bank of the
Auglaize River.
 
   (c)    Design Review Board.
(1)    Establishment. There is hereby established a Design Review Board to
review sign requests for the Central Business District.
(2)    Composition. The Board shall consist of three members as follows: the
Building Commissioner, Architect and one member of the downtown retail
merchants division of the Defiance Area Chamber of Commerce.
(3)    Appointment. The Mayor, with the approval and consent of Council, shall
appoint the members of the Board.
(4)    Terms. Members of the Board shall serve two-year terms, except for the
Building Commissioner, who shall be a permanent member while holding such
position. In order that the terms of the other two members will run so as to
have one experienced member in addition to the Building Commissioner at all
times, the first appointment will consist of one two- year term and one three
year term, becoming two years each thereafter.
(5)    Meetings and decisions. The Board shall meet monthly, as needed, and
shall render decisions within ten days after a hearing.
(6)    Reference standards for decisions. In determining requests for signs,
the Board shall refer to the following standards:
A.    The Master Plan of the Defiance Area Chamber of Commerce, as proposed
September, 1987;
B.    Sign Options and Criteria for the Defiance Central Business District,
sponsored by the Defiance Area Chamber of Commerce, June 26, 1987; and
C.    The provisions of this chapter.
(7)    Appeals. Any party adversely affected by a determination of the Board
may appeal to the Board of Zoning and Building Appeals pursuant to Section
7.03 of the City Charter.
 
   (d)    Restrictions and Requirements. Restrictions and requirements
regarding signs and other advertising structures within the Central Business
District shall be as follows:
(1)    Copy shall be limited to the basic statement of name and nature of
business.
(2)    Mounting heights between a minimum of ten feet and a maximum of fourteen
feet above the pavement shall be maintained, unless otherwise authorized by the
Design Review Board.
(3)    The minimum distance between the ends of a sign and the end of the
building shall be two feet.
(4)    The maximum height of the letters shall be sixteen inches.
(5)    The maximum height of the sign shall be two and one-half feet.
(6)    Sign area shall be calculated by multiplying the front linear footage of
the shop times 1.25, which shall be equal to the total sign area in square
feet.
(7)    Sign area for neon signs shall be calculated by multiplying the front
linear footage of the shop times . 75, which shall be equal to the total sign
area in square feet.
(8)    Professionally hand-lettered windows shall not cover more than twenty-
five percent of the area of the window and/or twenty-five percent of the total
glazed area of the building or shop. Letters shall not be larger than nine
inches.
(9)    Projecting signs shall not be lit internally. Their maximum dimensions
shall be three feet long by two feet, six inches high and they shall be able to
be supported without guy wires or any other means of support other than the
hanging bracket.
(10)    Pylon or pole signs and vacuform box signs are prohibited. Exceptions
may be authorized by the Board.
         (Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
 
1337.11 MAINTENANCE OF NON-CONFORMING SIGNS.
   A sign that was lawfully erected but fails to comply with one or more
subsequently enacted regulations may be maintained and used but shall not be
substantially improved, enlarged or otherwise altered except in conformity with
Chapter
1181.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
 
1337.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 6283. Passed 3-26-02.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1339
Maintenance Standards
1339.01   Maintenance of facilities and equipment.
1339.02   Maintenance of buildings.
1339.03   Maintenance of exterior areas.
1339.04   Dangerous structure defined.
 
1339.01 MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT.
   Every structure erected or constructed in conformity with the Ohio Building
Code, the Ohio Residential Code for One, Two and Three Family Dwellings,
Permanent Foundations Guide for Manufactured Housing or any other technical
code adopted by Ordinance, or in conformity with any local Ordinance or State
law or regulation, shall be maintained so as to keep all facilities, appliances
and equipment required by such technical codes, Ordinances or Laws in effect at
the time of construction in satisfactory working condition. The maintenance
required by this section includes, but is not limited to, the obligations to:
   (a)    Maintain all circuit breakers and fuses at an amperage that does not
exceed the safe load capacity of the wiring protected thereby and to replace
all electrical wiring that is improperly or inadequately insulated;
   (b)    Maintain all mechanical ventilation systems in efficient working
order and fitted with appropriate screens to prevent the entry of vermin and
insects;
(c)    Maintain all plumbing fixtures and all water and waste pipes in a
sanitary condition, free from defects, leaks and obstructions;
   (d)    Maintain all water heating devices and furnaces in good working order
and efficiently vented;
   (e)    Maintain all fire detection and suppression equipment in proper
working order and properly supplied with electricity and water necessary to the
operation thereof;
   (f)    Keep all required avenues of ingress and egress open, free of
obstructions and properly lighted.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1339.02 MAINTENANCE OF BUILDINGS.
   Every building, (including, without limitation: all commercial and
industrial buildings, dwellings, industrialized units and manufactured housing
units, and all garages, storage sheds and similar structures accessory thereto)
shall be maintained so as to keep the foundation, floor, outer walls, ceilings
and roof weathertight, watertight and rodentproof. Every window, exterior door
and basement hatchway or stairway shall be maintained in a weathertight, water
tight and rodentproof, condition and kept in good working order and repair.
Every inside and outside stair and handrail, and every porch and rail, shall be
so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the maximum load
that normal use may cause to be placed thereon, and shall be kept in sound
condition and good repair.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1339.03 MAINTENANCE OF EXTERIOR AREAS.
   No occupant or owner of any land shall cause or permit the maintenance of
any condition on the premises that debases the appearance of or reduces
property values in the neighborhood; creates a fire, safety or health hazard;
or constitutes a public nuisance including, but not limited to the following:
   (a)    Broken or dilapidated fences, walls or other exterior appurtenant
structures;
   (b)    Accumulations of unsightly debris including, without limitation:
garbage; waste, household refuse; unlicensed motor vehicles; used automobile
parts; broken, dilapidated or unusable furniture, mattresses or other household
furnishings, unused or unusable appliances, plastic materials, and rugs, rags
and other fabric materials hung on lines or in other places on or about the
exterior of the premises other than those placed outside to dry incident to
general household and housekeeping activities.
    (c)    Public sidewalks, interior walkways, driveways or driveway aprons
that are defective in any of the following particulars:
      (1)   Concrete or asphalt slabs fragmented by cracks into four or more
sections where any one of the gaps between the fragments is greater than 1/
4 inch in width;
      (2)   Vertical misalignment along any part of the seam between two slabs,
or between sections of a slab, of 1 inch or more;
      (3)   Blocks having a transverse slope in excess of 5/8 inch per
horizontal foot toward the street ar the adjoining property;
      (4)   Any surface irregularity that allows the impounding of water for
more than one square foot;
      (5)   Blocks having disintegrated or deteriorated areas.
         (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1339.04 DANGEROUS STRUCTURE DEFINED.
   Any building, dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, industrialized unit,
manufactured housing unit or other structure, or any separately secured part
thereof, that has one or more of the following defects shall be deemed
dangerous:
   (a)   Bearing walls or other vertical structural members that list, lean or
buckle to such an extent as to weaken the structural support provided;
   (b)    Supporting members that have sustained damage or suffered
deterioration amounting to thirty-three percent (33%) or more of the value of
the structure exclusive of the foundation;
   (c)    Nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering that have
sustained damage or suffered deterioration amounting to fifty percent (50%) or
more of the value of the structure exclusive of the foundation;
   (d)    Improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs, or floors or
roofs that have insufficient strength to support the loads presented by use
made of the structure with reasonable safety;
   (e)    Parts that are attached in an insecure manner as to create a risk of
injury to persons on the premises or to the public in the event of windstorm;
   (f)    Inadequate means of ingress and egress for the use made of the
structure under standards established by this Building Code or by the Ohio Fire
Code;
   (g)    Decay, rot, or infestation by insects or vermin to such an extent as
is likely to cause sickness or disease;
   (h)    Unsanitary accumulations of garbage, biodegradable wastes or rubbish
likely to cause sickness or disease;
   (i)    Accumulations of combustible wastes, refuse or rubbish to an extent
that presents an unreasonable risk of fire;
   (j)   Accumulations of paints, solvents, oils, grease, chemicals, or other
specially regulated substances maintained in violation of the Ohio Fire Code or
applicable regulations promulgated by the Ohio Fire Marshal or Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency;
   (k)    Structures lacking light, air and sanitation facilities required by
Section
1335.02 for the protection of the health and safety of human beings who live or
may live therein.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
CHAPTER 1341
Demolition Standards
1341.01   Permit required.
1341.02   Permit applications.
1341.03   Permit restrictions.
1341.04   Maintenance of vacant lots.
1341.05   Filling required; unsafe conditions.
1341.99   Penalties.
 
1341.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No owner of any property shall knowingly permit the demolition of any
structure to begin without having obtained a permit therefor. No contractor
shall commence demolition without knowledge of the existence of such a permit.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1341.02 PERMIT APPLICATIONS.
   Applications for the issuance of a Demolition Permit shall be filed with the
Building and Zoning Commissioner upon forms prescribed by the Commissioner.
Said application shall require disclosure of the following information:
   (a)    The location of the building to be demolished;
   (b)    The name, residence address and telephone number of all persons or
legal entities possessing an interest in the premises of record;
   (c)    The name, business address and Certificate of Registration Number of
the Registered Building Contractor to perform the work;
   (d)    Satisfactory evidence that all tests required by EPA Regulations to
determine the presence of asbestos or other hazardous materials on the premises
have been performed, the results of any such tests and, if the presence of
asbestos or other hazardous materials is established by the test results,
satisfactory evidence that the Building Contractor engaged to perform the work
is qualified to handle such materials and that the proposed manner and place of
disposal of hazardous materials is lawful and appropriate;
   (e)    The date on which work is to begin;
   (f)   The date on which all work is to be completed;
   (g)    The manner in which and place at which all construction rubble and
debris is to be disposed of;
   (h)    Satisfactory evidence that all requirements of Chapter
1353 have been met;
   (i)    A statement identifying all utilities that have or previously had
service connections to the premises and written evidence from each utility
confirming that its service connection has been sealed and all appurtenant
equipment removed.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1341.03 PERMIT RESTRICTIONS.
A Demolition Permit issued pursuant to this chapter may require:
   (a)    That work be performed during designated hours to minimize the
effects of noise and/or dust upon neighboring properties;
   (b)    That debris be removed from the premises by designated routes, at
designated times or by vehicles not exceeding a specified maximum gross loaded
weight so as to minimize interference with normal traffic patterns, minimize
public exposure to dust, debris or hazardous materials and avoid overburdening
public streets with excessive loads; and,
   (c)    Water spray or other techniques be used to minimize dust and air
borne contaminants.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1341.04 MAINTENANCE OF VACANT LOTS.
   Within ten days following demolition of any structure, the vacant lot shall
be filled, and graded to the established street elevation at curb level and
thereafter be maintained free from the accumulation of water, rubbish and all
other unsafe, unsanitary or hazardous conditions and adequate provisions shall
be made to prevent damage to any adjacent property due to loss of subjacent
support, subsidence, accumulation of excess water, accelerated storm water run-
off or other foreseeable causes resulting from the demolition.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1341.05 FILLING REQUIRED; UNSAFE CONDITIONS.
   No owner of any real estate upon which demolition has occurred shall fail to
fill the vacant lot or maintain such lot free from unsafe or hazardous
conditions as required by Section
1341.04.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1341.99 PENALTIES.
   (a)    Violation of Section
1341.01 of this chapter constitutes a misdemeanor of the first degree.
   (b)    Violation of Section
1341.05 of this chapter constitutes a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during which the premises
are not in compliance with the requirements of Section
1341.04.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)

1351.01 ADOPTION OF STANDARDS FOR REHABILITATION; DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   There is hereby adopted the United States Secretary of the Interior's
Standards for Rehabilitation, as amended from time to time (hereinafter called
"the Standards"), for the Downtown Improvement District, which is bounded on
the east by Wayne Avenue (including commercial properties on either side of
Wayne Avenue), on the south by Juliet Street (including one-half block south),
on the west by Perry Street (including commercial properties on either side of
Perry Street) and on the north by the Maumee River. A true and complete copy of
the Standards shall by kept on file at the City's principal office by the City
Administrator.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1351.02 REHABILITATION BOARD OF REVIEW; APPOINTMENTS; REMOVALS; ADOPTION OF
RULES AND PROCEDURES.
   (a)   Council, upon recommendation by the Mayor, is empowered to appoint a
five-member Rehabilitation Board of Review (hereinafter called “the Board”),
each member of which shall have some association with, connection to or special
interest in the City, which may include, by way of example, residency or
employment in the City. One member shall be a member of the City’s Planning
Commission. Two members shall be appointed with the approval of the Board of
Directors of the Defiance Development and Visitors’ Bureau or its successor-in-
interest. One member shall have some specialized training in architecture or
engineering. One member shall be from the City’s Building Inspection Division.
   (b)    Board members shall be appointed for terms of six years each, except
that the term of one member of the first Board shall be for four years and the
terms of two members of the first Board shall be for two years. All members
shall serve without compensation. Vacancies may be filled for the unexpired
terms only.
   (c)    Board members may be appointed to successive terms without
limitation.
   (d)    The Board may recommend removal of any member for good cause. Good
cause shall include, without limitation, failure of a member to perform
appointed duties or unethical conduct. Following review, the Board may request
Council to remove the member based upon review findings.
   Upon failure of a Board member to attend three consecutive Board meetings,
or upon failure to attend thirty percent or more of the Board's meetings within
any twelve-month period, the Board shall review the circumstances relative to
the member's attendance. Following the review, the Board may request Council to
remove the member based upon review findings.
   (e)    If any Board member ceases to have some association with, connection
to or special interest in the City (other than his or her being a Board
member), the same shall constitute his or her resignation from the Board,
effective upon the date a replacement is appointed by Council upon
recommendation by the Mayor.
   (f)   The Board shall meet quarterly at which time it shall review funding
applications on first-come, first-served basis.
   (g)    The Board may adopt its own rules and procedures, which shall be
similar in form and content to those used by the City Planning Commission.
(Ord. 8441. Passed 9-13-22.)
1351.03 CERTIFICATES OF APPROPRIATENESS REQUIRED; ISSUANCE; APPEALS.
   (a)    Any owner of real property utilizing grant funds (whether an
individual, partnership, corporation or otherwise) who applies for a building,
sign or demolition permit related, in whole or in part, to exterior
construction or improvement in the Downtown Improvement District, shall obtain
a certificate of appropriateness (hereinafter called "a certificate") or a
conditional certificate from the Board as a condition precedent to receipt of
the building, sign or demolition permit. The owner may obtain a certificate by
filing an application therefor with the Building and Zoning Commissioner, which
application shall include sufficient documentation and information to enable
the Rehabilitation Board of Review to determine if the proposed work will
conform to the Standards. Within twenty-one days after an application for
conformity with the Standards, notice of the date, time and place of the
Board's meeting shall be given to the owner at the address set forth on the
owner's application by certified mail not less than seven days prior to the
date on which such meeting is held. With consent of the owner, the date, time
or place of such meeting may be rescheduled.
   (b)    If the Board finds that the proposed work substantially conforms to
the Standards, it shall issue a certificate.
   (c)    If the Board finds that the proposed work does not substantially
conform to the Standards but that modifications can be made thereto so as to
result in substantial conformity with the Standards, the Board may issue a
conditional certificate, which shall describe all necessary modifications to be
taken by the owner to substantially conform to the Standards.
   (d)    If the Board finds that the proposed work does not substantially
conform to the Standards and that, more likely than not, a conditional
certificate cannot bring about substantial conformity with the Standards, the
Board shall deny a certificate.
   (e)    Any determination by the Board may be appealed, in writing, by the
owner to Council for further review and final determination. Council shall
review the appeal and shall issue its determination no later than forty-five
days after receipt of the appeal.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1351.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
CHAPTER 1353
Historical Preservation
1353.01    Initiation of nominations for establishment of districts.
1353.02    Preparation of nominations.
1353.03    Approval of nominations.
1353.04    Criteria for approval.
1353.05    Certificates of appropriateness required.
1353.06    Certificate applications.
1353.07    Demolition plans.
1353.08    Issuance of certificates; action by Historical Preservation Review
Commission.
1353.09    Conformity to statutory requirements.
1353.10    Repair and maintenance of buildings.
1353.11    Enforcement of chapter.
1353.12    Declaration of nuisance.
1353.13    Conflicts with Zoning Code.
1353.14    Appeals to Council.
1353.15    Judicial review.
1353.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Ohio Historical Society - see Ohio R.C. 149.30, 149.31
Historical sites - see Ohio R. C. 149.301
Registration of historic landmarks - see Ohio R. C. 149.55
Prehistorical sites - see Ohio R. C. 1743.07
Historical Preservation Review Commission - see ADM. Ch.
163
 
1353.01 INITIATION OF NOMINATIONS FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS.
   A recommendation for establishing an Historical District or landmark site
may be initiated from either of the following two sources:
(a)    Based on its survey, the Historical Preservation Review Commission may
prepare and submit, in accordance with this chapter, Historical District or
landmark site nominations for Council approval. These nominations shall first
be submitted to the City Planning Commission for its review and comment. For
the purpose of this chapter, no building or site may be nominated for inclusion
in an Historical District or as an historical site unless the owner of that
building or site has so authorized the nomination.
   (b)    Owners of property in fee simple wishing to establish an Historical
District or landmark site which includes their property may petition the
Historical Preservation Review Commission to consider designating the property
to be processed as described in subsection (a) hereof.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.02  PREPARATION OF NOMINATIONS.
   In order to establish an Historical District or landmark site, the
Historical Preservation Review Commission shall prepare or order to have
prepared by the individual petitioning the Commission as described in Section
1353.01(b) a nomination describing the District or landmark site. This
nomination will follow guidelines for nominating the Historical District or
landmark site to the National Register of Historic Places (National
Preservation Act of 1966) and shall consist of two parts: a physical
description and a description of historic significance.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.03 APPROVAL OF NOMINATIONS.
   Before an Historical District or landmark site is established and the
building classifications take effect, the nomination setting forth its
boundaries and building classifications must be submitted to and approved in an
ordinance by Council. The procedure for doing so shall be as follows:
   (a)   In accordance with Section
1353.02, the Historical Preservation Review Commission must take official
action deciding whether or not to submit a nomination to Council for its
approval.
   (b)    Prior to taking action at a meeting, the Commission shall hold a
public hearing to allow public comment. A public hearing may be held separately
or in conjunction with the meeting where action on the District is to occur.
   (c)   A public hearing held by the Commission for the purpose of allowing
comment on a proposed Historical District or landmark site designation shall be
preceded by public notice printed twenty days prior to the hearing.
   (d)   Before submitting a nomination to Council, the Historical Preservation
Review Commission shall first submit it to the City Planning Commission for its
review and comment.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.04  CRITERIA FOR APPROVAL.
   An Historical District or landmark site shall not be established unless the
proposed nomination includes groups of buildings, structures, sites, monuments,
streetscapes or neighborhoods which meet at least one of the following
criteria:
   (a)    Historic.
      (1)    Has significant character, interest or value as part of the
development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the City, State or nation,
or is associated with the life of a person significant in the past;
      (2)   Is the site of an historic event with a significant effect upon
society;
      (3)   Exemplifies the cultural, political, economic, social or historic
heritage of the community; or
      (4)   Has significant archaeological value as part of the community's
heritage.
   (b)   Architecturally Worthy.
      (1)    Portrays the environment in an era of history characterized by a
distinctive architectural style;
      (2)    Embodies those distinguishing characteristics of an architectural
or engineering type;
      (3)    Is the work of a designer whose individual work has significantly
influenced the development of the community;
      (4)    Is the work of a designer of such prominence that the work gains
its value from the designer's reputation;
      (5)    Contains elements of design detail, materials or craftsmanship
which represent a significant innovation;
      (6)    Contains any architectural style, detail or other element in
danger of becoming extinct; or
      (7)    Owing to its unique location or physical characteristics,
represents an established and familiar visual feature of a neighborhood or the
City.
         (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.05  CERTIFICATES OF APPROPRIATENESS REQUIRED.
   A certificate of appropriateness shall be issued by the Historical
Preservation Review Commission before a permit is issued for, or work is begun
on, any of the following within all areas of an Historical District or landmark
site:
(a)    The demolition of any building;
(b)    The moving of any building;
(c)    A conspicuous change in the exterior appearance of any historical
building or any part of or appurtenance to such a building, including walls,
fences, light fixtures, steps, paving and signs, by additions, reconstruction,
alteration or maintenance involving exterior color change;
(d)   Any new construction of a principal building or accessory building or
structure subject to view from a public way;
(e)    Conspicuous and visible changes within the public right of way;
   (f)   A change in walls and fences, or the construction of walls and fences,
along public ways in a primary area of an Historical District; or
   (g)   A conspicuous change in the exterior appearance of nonhistorical
buildings subject to view from a public way in a primary area of an Historical
District by additions, reconstruction, alteration or maintenance involving an
exterior color change.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.06 CERTIFICATE APPLICATIONS.
   An application for a certificate of appropriateness may be made in the
office of the City Administrator on forms provided by that office and shall be
subject to the following requirements:
(a)    The Historical Preservation Review Commission may adopt, as a part of
its rules, filing requirements which it finds reasonable and necessary to
expedite the business of the Commission. These rules may include, but are not
limited to, filing deadlines and application requirements, such as sketches,
drawings, photographs, descriptions or other information which the Commission
requires to make a decision.
(b)    No fee shall be charged for this application.
      (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.07  DEMOLITION PLANS.
   Any person desiring the demolition of any landmark or site not a part of an
Historical District or listed on the National Register shall submit a
demolition plan of a building or site designated by the Historical Preservation
Review Commission as being of historic interest before a demolition permit is
issued. The Commission shall review demolition plans within ten days from the
date of the demolition request.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.08 ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES; ACTION BY HISTORICAL PRESERVATION REVIEW
COMMISSION.
   The Historical Preservation Review Commission may approve certificates of
appropriateness for any actions covered by this chapter, as follows:
(a)    If an application for a certificate of appropriateness is approved by
the Commission or is not acted on by the Commission within thirty days after it
is filed, a certificate of appropriateness shall be issued after which required
permits and work may proceed as authorized by the certificate of
appropriateness.
(b)    If the Commission denies an application for a certificate of
appropriateness within thirty days after it is filed, the certificate may not
be issued. In this case, the Commission shall state its reasons for the denial
in writing and advise the applicant.
(c)    The Commission may grant an extension of the thirty-day limit prescribed
by subsections (a) and (b) hereof if the applicant agrees to it.
(d)    The Commission may advise and make recommendations to the applicant
before acting on an application for a certificate of appropriateness .
   (Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.09  CONFORMITY TO STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.
   Historical buildings shall be maintained to meet all applicable requirements
established under statute for buildings generally. All the characteristics of
an Historical District existing at the time the District was approved must be
maintained unless changes are approved by the Historical Preservation Review
Commission.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.10 REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE OF BUILDINGS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed so as to prevent the ordinary
repair and maintenance of any building, structure or site, provided that the
repair or maintenance does not result in a conspicuous change in the design,
form, proportion, mass, configuration, building material, texture, color,
location or external visual appearance of any structure or part thereof.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.11 ENFORCEMENT OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall be enforced using personnel and policies designated by
the City Administrator.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.12  DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
   The erection, construction, enlargement, alteration, repair, demolition,
color change, moving or maintenance of any building, structure or appurtenance
which is begun, continued or maintained contrary to any of the provisions of
this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance, in violation of this chapter
and unlawful.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.13 CONFLICTS WITH ZONING CODE.
   Zoning districts lying within the boundaries of the Historical District are
subject to regulations for both the zoning district and the Historical
District. If there is a conflict between the requirements of the zoning
district and the requirements of the Historical District, the more restrictive
requirements shall apply. Requirements which apply to the safety and health of
the populace shall take precedence.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.14 APPEALS TO COUNCIL.
   If an application for a certificate of appropriateness is denied, a copy of
the minutes of the meeting and written reasons for the denial shall be given to
the applicant. The applicant shall have thirty days from the date of the denial
to appeal the denial to Council. Upon receipt of the appeal, Council shall have
sixty days in which to schedule any necessary hearings and make a final
determination on the merits of the appeal.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.15 JUDICIAL REVIEW.
   Any person or party aggrieved by a decision or action taken by the
Historical Preservation Review Commission or Council shall be entitled to a
judicial review.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1353.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A thirty-day grace period shall be
granted for compliance, after which period a separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
CHAPTER 1355
Residential Antidisplacement and Relocation Assistance Plan
1355.01    Adoption.
1355.02    Replacement of housing.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Demolition of buildings - see B. & H. Ch.
1341
Housing Code - see B. & H. Ch.
1335
 
1355.01 ADOPTION.
   Council hereby adopts an Antidisplacement and Relocation Assistance Plan as
attached to original Resolution 2139, passed April 3, 1990, and incorporated
herein by reference.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
1355.02 REPLACEMENT OF HOUSING.
   (a)    The City will replace all occupied and vacant occupiable low/moderate
income dwelling units demolished or converted to a use other than as low/
moderate income housing as a direct result of activities assisted with funds
provided under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, as amended
(the Act), as described in 24 CFR 570.496 (a)(1).
   (b)    All replacement housing will be provided within three years of the
commencement of the demolition or rehabilitation to conversion. Before
obligating or expending funds that will directly result in such demolition or
conversion, the City will make public and submit to the Office of Local
Government Services the following information in writing:
(1)    A description of the proposed assisted activity;
(2)    The general location on a map and approximate number of dwelling units
by size (number of bedrooms) that will be demolished or converted to a use
other than as low/moderate income dwelling units as a direct result of the
assisted activity;
(3)    A time schedule for the commencement and completion of the demolition or
conversion;
(4)    The general location on a map and approximate number of dwelling units
by size (number of bedrooms) that will be provided as replacement dwelling
units;
(5)    The source of funding and a time schedule for the provision of
replacement dwelling units;
(6)    The basis for concluding that each replacement dwelling unit will remain
a low/moderate dwelling unit for at least ten years from the date of initial
occupancy;
(7)    An analysis determining whether a dwelling unit proposed to be
demolished is occupiable or not; and
(8)    An analysis determining whether a dwelling unit proposed to be
demolished or converted is considered a low/moderate income unit.
   (c)    The City will provide relocation assistance, as described in 24 CFR
570.496(b)(2), to each low/moderate income household displaced by the
demolition of housing or by the conversion of a low/moderate income dwelling to
another use as a direct result of assisted activities.
   (d)    Consistent with the goals and objectives of activities assisted under
the Act, the City agrees to provide substantial levels of assistance
displacement of persons displaced by HUD-assisted programs and will further
seek to minimize displacement of persons as a result of assisted activities.
(Ord. 6223. Passed 6-12-01.)
CHAPTER 1357
Equal Housing Opportunity
1357.01    Policy.
1357.02    Scope.
1357.03    Definitions.
1357.04    Unlawful housing practices.
1357.05    Posting of notices.
1357.06    Procedures and enforcement.
1357.07    Other legal action.
1357.08    Severability.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Ohio Civil Rights Commission - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4112
      Unlawful discriminatory practices - see Ohio R.C. 4112.02
      Civil action to protect fair housing rights - see Ohio R.C. 4112.052
1357.01 POLICY.
   It is hereby designated to be the policy of the Municipality of Defiance to
do all things necessary and proper to secure for all its citizens their right
to equal housing opportunities, regardless of their race, color, national
origin. religion, sex, familial status, handicap, disability or military
status. (Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.02 SCOPE.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all housing located within the
territorial limits of the City. (Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.03 DEFINITIONS.
   The definitions set forth in this Section shall apply throughout this
Resolution:
   (a)   “REAL ESTATE AGENT"
      Real Estate Agent includes any real estate broker. real estate salesman,
or any agent thereof. or any other person, partnership association, or
corporation who for consideration sells, purchases, exchanges, rents,
negotiates, offers, or attempts to negotiate the sale or the purchase, exchange
or rental of real property, or holds himself out as engaged in the business of
selling, purchasing. exchanging, renting or otherwise transferring any interest
in real property.
   (b)   "DISCRIMINATION, DISCRIMINATING, OR DISCRIMINATE"
The terms discrimination, discriminating, or discriminate means to render any
difference in the sale, lease, rental, or financing of a dwelling or housing
unit because of a person's race, color, national origin, religion, sex,
familial status, handicap, disability or military status.
   (c)   "HOUSING OR DWELLING"
Housing means any building, facility, or structure or port thereof which is
used or occupied or intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied as
the home, residence, or sleeping place of one or more persons.
   (d)   "LENDING INSTITUTION"
Lending institutions means any bank, insurance company, savings and loan
associations, or any other person or organization regularly engaged in the
business of lending money or guaranteeing loans.
   (e)   "PERSON"
Person means one or more individuals, corporations. partnerships, associations,
labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock
companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, trustees in
bankruptcy, receivers, and fiduciaries.
   (f)   "FAMILIAL STATUS"
      Familial status means one or more individuals {'{'}who have not attained
the age of eighteen (18) years) being domiciled with:
      (1)   A parent or another person having legal custody of such an
individual or individuals, or
      (2)    The designee of such parent or other persons having such custody,
with the written permission of such parent or other person. The protection
afforded against discrimination on the basis of familial status shall apply to
any person who is pregnant, or in the process of securing legal custody of any
individual who has not attained the age of eighteen (18).
   (g)   "MILITARY"
Military means a person's status in "service in the uniformedservices." The
performance of duty, on a voluntary or involuntary basis, in a uniformed
service, under competent authority, and includes active duty for training,
initial active duty for training, inactive duty for training, full-time
national guard duty, and performance of duty or training by a member of the
Ohio organized militia.
   (h)   "HANDICAP"
Handicap means, with respect to a person:
      (1)   A physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or
more of such person's major life activities,
      (2)   A record of having such an impairment, or
      (3)    Being regarded as having such an impairment, but such term does
not include current, illegal use of or addiction to a controlled substance (as
defined in Section 102 of the Controlled Substance Act (21 US.C 802))
         (Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.04 UNLAWFUL HOUSING PRACTICES.
   It shall be an unlawful housing practice and a violation of this resolution:
   (a)   For Any Person or Real Estate Agent.
      (1)   To refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent. assign or refuse the
transfer of any interest in a dwelling after the making of a bona fide offer,
or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make
unavailable or deny, or make false representations on the availability of a
dwelling to any person because of race, color, national origin, religion, sex,
familial status, handicap, disability or military status.
      (2)    To include in the terms, conditions, or privileges of any sale,
lease, sublease, rental, assignment, or other transfer pf any housing, any
clause, condition, or restriction discriminating against any person in the use
or occupancy of such housing because of race. color, national origin, religion,
sex, familial status, handicap, disability or military status.
      (3)    To discriminate in the furnishing of any facilities,repairs,
improvements, or services pr in the terms, conditions, privileges, or tenure of
occupancy of any person because of race, color, national origin, religion, sex,
familial status, handicap, disability or military status.
      (4)    To publish or circulate or cause to be published or circulated any
notice, statement, listing, or advertisement, or to announce a policy or to
make any record in connection with the prospective sale, lease, sublease,
rental, or financing of any housing which indicates reliance, determination or
decision based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, familial status,
handicap, disability or military status.
      (5)    To assist in, compel, or coerce the doing of any act declared to
be an unlawful housing practice under this resolution or to obstruct or prevent
enforcement or compliance with provisions of this resolution or to attempt
directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this resolution to be an
unlawful housing practice.
      (6)   To induce or attempt to induce the sale, transfer of interest, or
listing for sale of any housing by making representations regarding the
existing or potential proximity of real property owned, used, or occupied by
any particular race, color, national origin, religion, sex, familial status,
handicap. disability or military status by direct or indirect methods.
      (7)    To make any representation to a prospective purchaser or lessee
that any housing in a particular block, neighborhood, or area may undergo, is
undergoing, or had undergone a change with respect to racial, color, religion,
nationality, or ethnic composition of such block, neighborhood or area.
      (8)    To induce or attempt to induce the sale or listing for sale of any
housing by representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of
any particular race, color, national origin, religion, sex, familial status,
handicap, disability or military status in the area will or may result in:
         A.   Lowering of property values.
         B.   A change in the racial, color, religious, nationality, or ethnic
composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is
located.
         C.   An increase in criminal or antisocial behavior in the area.
         D.   A decline in quality of the schools serving the area.
      (9)    To cause or coerce or attempt to cause or coerce retaliation
against any person because such person has lawfully opposed any act or failure
to act that is in violation of this chapter or has, in good faith, filed a
complaint. testified, participated. or assisted in any way in any proceeding
under this chapter.
   (b)   Lending Institutions. Lending institutions shall not discriminate in
lending money, quaranteeinq loans, accepting a deed or trust or mortgage, or
otherwise making available funds for the purchase. acquisition, construction,
alteration, rehabilitation, repair, or maintenance of any housing, or
discriminate in the fixing of the rates, terms. conditions, or provisions of
any such financial assistance because of race, color, national origin,
religion, sex, familial status, handicap, disability or military status.
   (c)   Association with a Housing Business Organization or Facility. It is
unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any
multi-listing service, real estate brokers' organization. or facility relating
to the business of selling or renting housing to discriminate against a person
in the terms or conditions of such access, membership, or participation.
   (d)   Other. It is unlawful to do any other thing or engage in conduct which
would otherwise make unavailable equal housing opportunities.
(Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.05 POSTING OF NOTICES.
   Every real estate agent shall post in a conspicuous location in that portion
of their business
normally used by them for negotiating the terms of a sale or lease of housing.
and each person who operates a multi-unit residential building containing more
than two units shall post at all times when prospective tenants are being
interviewed, in a conspicuous location in that portion of this housing business
normally used by them for negotiating the rental of a housing unit therein. a
notice which contains the following language printed in black on a light-
colored background, in not less than fourteen-point type:
   It is a violation of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968. which
includes the "Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988" for any real estate agent.
or for any person owning or managing a multi-unit apartment dwelling to:
   Deny housing to any person because of race, color, national origin,
religion, sex, familial
status, handicap, disability or military status: and/or Discriminate against
any person because of that person's race, color. national origin, religion,
sex, familial status, handicap. disability or military status with respect to
the terms, conditions, or privileges of housing accommodations or in the
furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith.
IF YOU BELIEVE YOU HAVE BEEN DISCRIMINATED AGAINST. CONTACT THE MAUMEE VALLEY
PLANNING ORGANIZATION (MVPOJ FAIR HOUSING OFFICE (FAIR HOUSING COORDINATOR) AT
419-784-3882, THE OHIO CIVIL RIGHTS COMMISSION (OCRC) AT 419-245-2900, OR THE
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT (HUD) AT 1-800-669-9777.
      (Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.06 PROCEDURES AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   Procedures.  It shall be the duty of the Fair Housing Coordinator or a
person under their direction to provide education and training about laws
against housing discrimination to the citizens of the City of Defiance. Work
closely with community organizations. housing providers. lenders and insurance
agencies to promote fair housing laws and goals. Offer referrals to appropriate
government agencies or organizations to assist anyone who believes they have
been discriminated against because of that person's race, color, national
origin, religion, sex, familial status, handicap, disability or military
status.
   (b)   Complaint Intake and Records. The Fair Housing Coordinator or a person
under their direction will receive written, signed and oral complaints and will
record, review, and perform limited investigations of each complaint. Once the
initial intake is complete, the person(s) filing the complaint may then be
referred to the Ohio Civil Rights Commission, and/or the U.S. Department of
Housing and Urban Development for possible further investigation and/or action
and/or will be given educational materials. All actions taken will be
documented and maintained according to the MVPO records policy.
(Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.07 OTHER LEGAL ACTION.
   Nothing contained in this resolution shall prevent any person from
exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which he might otherwise be
entitled or from filing any complaint with any other agency or court of law or
equity.
(Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
1357.08 SEVERABILITY.
   Sections and sub-sections of this resolution and the several parts and
provisions thereof are hereby declared to be independent sections, sub-
sections. parts, and provisions. and the holding of any such section, sub-
section, part, or provision thereof to be unconstitutional, void, or
ineffective for any cause, shall not affect nor render any other such section,
subsection, part. or provisions invalid, void, unconstitutional or ineffective.
(Ord. 8572. Passed 3-12-24.)
